title: Realms of the Haunting
comment:
- Great atmosphere
- Unique gameplay
- Art style holds up
- The mansion was a nice hub area
- Somehow the combat was actually fun because of the weapon switching
- A lot of the puzzles were hot garbage, made worse by the controls and the gamma settings
- FMV cutscenes need to make a comeback
- Low resolution textures made some text hard to read

title: FTL: Faster Than Light
comment: I'd like FTL much more if I wasn't so shit at it. The difficulty spike at the end especially bugs me. Still a fun game, even if I only played it at a very low level.

title: Serial Cleaner
comment: Only played a late early access version. Fun idea and I enjoyed the early levels, but enemies are too unpredictable in the larger levels and the random enemy type is just awful.

title: Distrust
comment: I love The Thing but the enemies and sanity effects in this weren't nearly interesting enough. Okay concept but not being able to increase the game speed or queue actions made everything feel really slow.

title: Hexcells
comment: Pretty good puzzle game.

title: Hexcells Plus
comment: Way harder than the first one but also the least good HexCells.

title: Hexcells Infinite
comment: Minesweeper but good, the perfect puzzle game, and comfy as heck. The infinite mode has consumed more time out of my life than anything should.

title: Assassin's Creed IV: Black Flag
comment: Way too many cutscenes and too much filler content, and overly simplistic gameplay.

title: Watch_Dogs
comment: Much like AC4. Bland.

title: Dead Space
comment: Great atmosphere and very satisfying combat, really happy the mouse controls got a fix so I finally got to play this. If you use a mouse, hard difficulty is a must.

title: Asghan: The Dragon Slayer
comment: Took forever to even get this to a near playable state and it wasn't worth it.

title: SquareCells
comment: HexCells is much better.

title: CrossCells
comment: SquareCells is much better.

title: Into the Breach
comment: Excellent tactics game. The ending isn't as big of a difficulty spike as in FTL and the achievement system adds a lot of replayability.

title: Sniper Elite 4
comment: By far the best in the series thanks to the open level design. The way enemies reacted to things was a bit all over the place but it didn't get in the way too much. The pistol being far more useful than the rifle felt odd.

title: Dead Space 2
comment: More the same, which is not necessarily a bad thing since Dead Space 1 was very good. Mechanically better, but lacks a bunch of things that made Dead Space 1 special.

title: Vanquish
comment: Could've been very good if it had a better health and damage indicators. Too often it was unclear if I was taking damage and if I was, from where and how much.

title: Manhunt
comment: First half was pretty amusing, second half was pretty frustrating. Limited saves added some tension to otherwise bland gameplay. Best worst stealth mechanics I've ever seen.

title: Alekhine's Gun
comment: Not nearly as bad as its reputation. For someone looking for more Hitman after 2/C/BM/2016, I'd recommend this and the first Death to Spies over C47/Absolution/DtS Moment of Truth. Shit rating system though.

title: Resident Evil 6
comment: It seems like it could be really fun with all the dodges and quickshots and wrestling moves and such, but the camera and controls feel like they have a mind of their own, making playing this just infuriating.

title: Hitman: Sniper Assassin
comment:
First impressions video:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VTf-IGUAnh0

title: Acid Spy
comment: Pretty decent arcade/stealth shooter/platformer, could make for a really good speedrun plus the dev is awesome and responds well to feedback. Gameplay and visuals do get pretty repetitive though.

title: Max Payne 2: The Fall of Max Payne
comment: Casual playthrough, watched all cutscenes, didn't use any skips etc. One of the best shooters ever made, short but no filler anywhere.
finished: Dead on Arrival, no bullet time

title: Tametsi
comment: Wants to be a deeper Hexcells, feels like an overly complex MineSweeper. Couldn't be bothered with clean completions or the extra puzzles.

title: The Evil Within
comment: Liked this a lot. Good gameplay and atmosphere but very linear and had some really cheap kills. Compared to Dead Space, more variety but worse level design and storytelling. DS1>TEW>DS2.

title: S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Call of Pripyat
comment: Completed pretty much all missions I could. Amazing atmosphere and setting, a rare case of me liking an open world game. The ending was crap but overall a really damn good game.

title: Tom Clancy's Splinter Cell: Blacklist
comment: The stealth was pretty alright, but got a bit repetitive and I prefer the sandbox maps of Hitman. Still pretty good other than the train yard mission and the final boss QTEs.

title: S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow of Chernobyl
comment: Way too much combat with humans and not enough exploration. The Zone is the best part of the game but it's hard to appreciate it when some generic bandit keeps attacking you all the damn time.

title: Thief Gold
comment: Gameplay still holds up surprisingly well and sound design is great, but the level design is just bad with a few exceptions. I may not like Thief a lot, but I kinda appreciate it anyway.

title: Alpha Protocol
comment: It's very much jank, but the funny kind at least with a pistol/stealth build. Skills are completely busted and dialogue and the branching story are well made, but I just didn't give a crap about the main storyline.

title: Divinity: Original Sin - Enhanced Edition
comment: Got sick of getting destroyed in every encounter, misclicks caused by enemy idle animations, headache inducing camera and micromanaging equipment. Exploring the town was fun but that's about it.

title: The Slater
comment: For a budget Hitman clone it's pretty good, for a one man project it's incredible.

title: Volume
comment: Didn't plan on beating this in one sitting but did anyway as it was short and well paced. Decent stealth game, fun for one evening.

title: Party Hard 2
comment: Frustrating and confusing. The game was bad at making it clear what you can get away with and the stamina system should be burned. Wasted potential.

title: Call of Cthulhu
comment: About as good as Dark Corners. Nothing is as good as Attack of the Fishmen but nothing as bad as Air Filled Tunnels either. The low budget shows but I liked it for how it handled the source material.

title: LYNE
comment: Was hoping for a Hexcells-like comfy puzzle game. Sorta comfy but didn't feel very puzzle-y, spamming educated guesses felt more efficient than actually thinking so I gave up on it.

title: HITMAN 2
comment: I don't fucking know.

title: The Talos Principle
comment: Most of the puzzles were good and I liked the atmosphere but holy fuck the recorder puzzles are awful. Hated everything involving that mechanic and don't feel even slightly bad for cheating past most of them.

title: The Talos Principle: Road to Gehenna
comment: Better puzzles and only two had recorder shit in them.

title: Sokobond
comment: It's no Hexcells, but one of the better minimalist puzzle games I've played. Might go back for the extra puzzles at some point.

title: HOOK
comment: Reminded me of unraveling 30 meters of RJ45-cable.

title: Opus Magnum
comment: Good game, even if it explained some mechanics poorly. I like these types of puzzles overall, but preferred optimizing the simpler early game stuff over getting the late game stuff to even function.

title: Thief
comment: Had an open mind going in but yep, it sucks. I didn't like TDP but it had a lot of good things in it, this was just a linear bore where the memorable bits were only memorable because they were bad/stupid/frustrating.

title: Metal Gear Solid V: Ground Zeroes
comment: Sometimes frustrating, but the map and missions are very well designed and varied and outside of the cover and checkpoint systems, the mechanics work smoothly.

title: Globesweeper
comment: It is what it claims to be. On par with Hexcells' randomized puzzles.

title: Darkness Within 2: The Dark Lineage - Director's Cut Edition
comment: Liked it for the Lovecraftian setting despite the story being nonsense and the first person movement distracted me enough from it being just a point'n'click adventure. Puzzles were often pretty crap.

title: Tunnel Rats
comment: Truly a classic among bad games. If only it ran decently on anything.

title: Kane & Lynch: Dead Men
comment: Very mediocre gameplay, but it didn't have a chance to get overly boring. Some of the changes in pace were pretty cool and a some really shit.

title: NEON STRUCT
comment: Stealth gameplay is pretty alright. Music is good. Aesthetic is decent. Level design is hit and miss. Storytelling sucks so I lost interest in the story.

title: Thief II: The Metal Age
comment: Way better level/mission design than in Thief 1, I'd only call 2/15 missions bad. The stealth mechanics are still very good and the audio design still excellent. The AI often seemed glitchy, but still a great game.

title: Slay the Spire
comment: Very chill game that was a lot of fun for a while, but eventually the RNG just got more tedious than interesting and I just can't be arsed to get good enough to learn to work around it.

title: Tom Clancy's Splinter Cell
comment: Extremely linear level design, finicky stealth mechanics, overall clumsy gameplay. It's hard to believe this came out over 2 years after Thief 2 and got a very positive reception.

title: The Sinking City
comment: It's alright. Would be better off with far less combat and a smaller world, but the setting and the investigations were neat. Better than CoC2018 in every individual aspect, but CoC2018 is still the better game overall.

title: Tom Clancy's Splinter Cell: Conviction
comment: With some small changes like making the AI less random and and prone to go to search mode it could've been decent, even good. Except for the last three missions, nothing can redeem that shit.

title: The Turing Test
comment: Decent puzzle game. Pretty comfy, but unremarkable.

title: Ronin
comment: Trying to mix real time with pause and turn based gameplay is not a good idea, and having built in tips acknowledge that a core mechanic is broken is not clever.

title: Gunpoint
comment: Actually clever puzzle/stealth game. Interesting mechanics, functioning rating system, good music, fun type of self awareness in writing. Bit puzzle heavy to have much lasting appeal, but worth a playthough for sure.

title: Tom Clancy's Splinter Cell: Chaos Theory
comment: The sound meter was a neat concept, but didn't work with the lacking sound design. Level design was better than in SC1, but still too linear for my liking. Overall mediocre, I have no idea how this series got so big.

title: Thief Simulator
comment: Heavily carried by its concept. Mechanically passable, but controls and especially the storytelling and the pacing could use more work. More okay than the name and the visuals imply.

title: Resident Evil
comment: Meaningful combat, plenty of long and short term decision making, open ended level design, very cool. The camera was trash and puzzles questionable, but the good far outweighs the bad.

title: Thief: Deadly Shadows
comment: Clunky movement, mostly pointless hub area, dull loot requirements. But still very enjoyable thanks to good and varied level design and solid stealth mechanics. Not as great as T2, but still very good.

title: Batman: Arkham Asylum
comment: Good pacing made it so that the different aspects didn't get stale. The predator rooms were the highlight, shame the game didn't let me play more of them in the poorly handled challenge mode.

title: Puzzle Quest: Challenge of the Warlords
comment: Poorly randomized Bejeweled with too many filler fights. Did not live up to nostalgia and the final boss can go heck itself, no shame in cheating there.

title: Conarium
comment: Like Darkness Within 2 but more of a walking sim and with a less interesting setting.

title: Tom Clancy's Splinter Cell: Double Agent
comment: As far as concepts go, definitely the most interest SC. But also mechanically busted and the worst PC port I've ever attempted to play.

title: HEIST
comment: Fun little stealth game with nice visuals, good sound design and interesting items. Could've really used a map screen and option to manually control taking cover.

title: Moons of Madness
comment: Interesting setting let down by boring storytelling, bland gameplay and lacking atmosphere. CoC2018 and DCotE > Sinking City > DW2 > MoM > Conarium.

title: Heat Signature
comment: Really wish this had a proper campaign and wasn't a roguelike so it wouldn't turn into a boring grind too early. Breaking into ships was good, but there just wasn't enough variety or interesting progression.

title: The Outer Worlds
comment: Good writing and I liked that the combat was completely avoidable. Supernova didn't really make the game hard, but added a couple of tedious elements that I could've done without.

title: Linelight
comment: Enjoyable enough puzzles and a great soundtrack. Shame about the last world, as with many puzzle games, the fun stops when self-duplication is introduced.

title: PAYDAY 2
comment:
The most noteworthy stealth game of the decade.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0je-SSpHxVw
finished: Solo/Stealth heists/Death Sentence One Down + random coop

title: Disco Elysium
comment: What a ride.

title: Sniper Ghost Warrior Contracts
comment: Objectives that discourage sniping, poor stealth mechanics, nothing feels polished or thought through, plenty of glitches. Nope.

title: Batman: Arkham City
comment: Like Arkham Asylum but more polished. Nothing about it is great except for Mark Hamill's Joker, and nothing about it is bad except for the Two Face fight.

title: Batman: Arkham Origins
comment: Like City but jankier, dumber and worse in general. The challenge system was a nice idea at least, even if the execution wasn't there.

title: GTFO
comment: Really good for an early access game, the stealth and the atmosphere are solid and it's great how you actually have to coordinate with a full team to make it.

title: SUPERHOT VR
comment: Is fun, perfect for VR. Wish throwing items was more accurate though.

title: Beat Saber
comment: Gameplay is fun, but the campaign is maybe the worst I've seen in any game and the scoring/failing system is really bad. Modding and custom songs would save it if the devs didn't feel the need to break everything with every patch.

title: SUPERHOT
comment: Like SHVR but with worse pacing and controls.

title: Reigns: Game of Thrones
comment: The decisions don't have enough context to be anything but uninformed guesses and somehow the controls are buggy.

title: Styx: Master of Shadows
comment: Nonsensical level design that relies on objective markers and doesn't make any logical sense, and a shadow system where the graphics don't match the binary mechanics.

title: Dishonored
comment: First half is great, second half not quite. Gameplay is generally really good, shame that the rating system is crap and it's really easy especially if you upgrade some abilities.

title: Death to Spies
comment: Maybe it's at least decent on a lower difficulty, but on Expert it's just excessively slow and punishing. At least the rating system is one of the better ones and it's interesting DtS had enforcers way before Hitman.

title: Dishonored: The Knife of Dunwall
comment: First mission was great, second was good but buggy, third was the worst map of the main game and it was still bad.

title: Dishonored: The Brigmore Witches
comment: All three maps were good, but not as good as TKoD's first map. Very good DLCs overall, much like the main game.

title: Darkness Within: In Pursuit of Loath Nolder
comment: Like the sequel, the music, atmosphere and setting are good but the puzzles are needlessy cryptic and nonsensical. I like the clue searching mechanic but it didn't seem to work as well as in DW2.

title: The Chronicles of Riddick: Escape from Butcher Bay - The Developer's Cut
comment: Stealth in complete darkness is neat, pacing is great and music is good, but the excessive reliance on scripted events and the terrible AI weigh it down.

title: DOOM 64
comment: Can't go wrong with classic Doom gameplay. Level design was very "something happened somewhere" but somehow most of it was sensible enough.

title: Half-Life: Alyx
comment: The VR part was disappointingly shallow, but the Half-Life part was pretty good. I got used to the controls after a few hours but they never stopped feeling clumsy.

title: Mark of the Ninja
comment: Might join Thief 2, Hitman Contracts and Payday 2 on my arbitrary list of noteworthy stealth games even if the amount of platforming make me not like it as much.

title: The Walking Dead: Saints & Sinners
comment: Don't know why I got this, I hate crafting and looting and this game is nothing but that. Melee combat was nice at least.

title: Final Fantasy X HD Remaster
comment:
Combat started off decent and chill, then halfway through devolved into dumb gimmick fights and culminated in a dumpster fire of a final boss.

(May have been a skill issue that using cheats escalated)

title: Party Hard
comment: Like the sequel, it's excessively random and repetitive and has a dreadful stamina system. At least the music is good and in this one the camera is better.

title: Batman: Arkham Knight
comment: More the same, maybe a bit more shallow combat and stealth. The car/tank sections are pointless and bad, but the side missions are handled much better than before.

title: Dungeon Warfare
comment: For tower defense, the campaign was actually pretty alright. Didn't do much to discourage doing the same strats in every level. Did a pretty good job at passing time without being demanding of stressful.

title: Alien: Isolation
comment: The Alien is pretty much the ideal enemy for a horror/stealth game and is was generally well handled. The androids not so much, but overall the game was still good.

title: Assassin's Creed
comment: Clumsy controls, mind numbing storytelling and repetitive gameplay that revolves around glorified minigames. Could've been a mix of Hitman and Prince of Persia, was a total mess.

title: Picklock
comment: It had some potential, but honestly felt more like a prototype or a student project than a finished game.

title: Far Cry 2: Fortune's Edition
comment: On paper it seems like it'd be interesting and unique but in practice it's neverending, pointless combat that isn't fun to begin with.

title: Dark
comment: Unbeliveably underrated, it's not great but it is far better than its 4/10 reputation. Might not be on Dishonored's level, but it's at least close to Aragami.

title: Wildfire
comment: I don't like 2D platforming and this is no exception even if it does focus on stealth. I'm no expert on sidescroller controls but this one felt really sluggish.

title: Middle-earth: Shadow of Mordor
comment: Batman but more blah. Taking out the warchiefs was almost a really good questline but the execution had a couple of giant holes in it.

title: Desperados: Wanted Dead or Alive
comment: The controls and UI do not hold up, especially in combat. Most of all it's just too difficult for its own good, I ended up cheesing some sections because that was the one approach that worked.

title: Archaica: The Path Of Light
comment: Standard beam/mirror puzzles. On the harder end of the scale, but the subtle enough hint system balances it out.

title: Desperados III
comment: Easily the best out of the few stealth/tactics games I've tried, probably because of the pause system. Still don't think the genre has peaked, I'd like to see less kills/KOs in the future as well as more open ended maps.

title: Spy Chameleon
comment: Feels like a stealth game intended for the precision platformer crowd, except it didn't feel very precise. The color changing gimmick is at least kinda clever.

title: Minit
comment: I don't see the appeal. The time limit doesn't do anything but artificially make the game longer.

title: Assassin's Creed II
comment: Better than AC1 but the first 7 hours were an absolute slog and while the last 7 were better, I wouldn't call them interesting. Why build an open world if you're going to waste it on linear missions?

title: Planescape: Torment - Enhanced Edition
comment:
Interesting and enjoyable enough, but D&D holds it back by unnecessarily messing with the gameplay and making the world harder to get into. Fumbled towards the end by having way too much action.
Updated my journal 249 times.

title: The Chronicles of Riddick: Assault on Dark Athena
comment: The first 4-5 hours would've made for a fitting expansion to EfBB as it was janky but well paced, but once reaching the planet surface it turned into a bland shooter with a dull gimmick gun.

title: Her Story
comment: The premise is interesting and pretty well executed, but the game felt pretty aimless especially at the beginning and ended very abruptly.

title: Control
comment: Pretty disappointed the promising looking map wasn't used like in Dark Souls or Resident Evil and the game was mostly linear with way too much combat. Still pretty alright, good concept and atmosphere.

title: Lucius
comment: Great concept, so it's a damn shame it plays more like an illogical point'n'click adventure rather than Hitman. Needed half the length and twice the depth.

title: Lucius II
comment: Should never have been released in such blatantly unfinished state. The first game wasn't great but had potential that could be used in a sequel, but this is just an insulting mess.

title: Styx: Shards of Darkness
comment: While the shadow mechanics and controls are improved, the levels are still built around following objective markers which just makes things boring. It's also extremely easy, even to ghost.
finished: Goblin, Insignias of Shadow and Mercy

title: Lucius Demake
comment: Lucius 1 but with a more fitting style.

title: Metal Gear Solid
comment: The plot/lore is the best kind of B-movie schlock that keeps on giving, but unfortunately between the cutscenes there is weak gameplay and some of the worst camera angles I've ever seen.

title: Dishonored 2
comment: It's good, just unexciting after D1. A Crack in The Slab was easily the highlight and felt original but other mission were just more the same. Would be better without the shoehorned in lethal/non-lethal options.

title: Hitman: Blood Money
comment: I don't think it's the best in the series (that's Contracts, at least until I casually replay that) but it is my favorite game of all time. Main takeaway from this casual playthrough is that I really like how the main story is told.

title: A Plague Tale: Innocence
comment: Looks and sounds nice, but ultimately it's a walking sim without enough gameplay depth to keep me playing.

title: The Escapists 2
comment: Prison break is a good setting for a stealth game but the crafting and random loot have no respect for the players time and make most of the game incredibly boring.

title: Lucius III
comment: It might be somewhat close to L1 quality wise, but after L2 it's really hard to not just laught at all the jank even if it isn't nearly as bad. What a weird series, playing them out of order might be a good move.

title: Hitman: Codename 47
comment: Mish mash of ideas many of which are interesting but don't work well or aren't communicated well. At its best when it's doing what became the usual Hitman thing (Traditions of the Trade).

title: Resident Evil 7 biohazard
comment: I like the Texas Chainsaw -setting/antagonists and the gameplay is very good, but it still doesn't come close to RE1. Mostly because the molded just don't make you plan your actions the way RE1 enemies did.

title: Tony Hawk's Pro Skater (N-Gage)
comment: Low draw distance, narrow field of view and somewhat uncomfortable handheld aside, it's a surprisingly good port and very fun for what it is. Or maybe the port sucks, I never played any other versions.

title: We Happy Few
comment: Looting, crafting, survival mechanics and open worlds are all things I typically dislike, plus this had horrible performance issues even on lowest settings.

title: System Shock: Enhanced Edition
comment: Despite some problems, the UI, controls, art style and music work together great and add up to something unique and interesting. I thought I'd hate the UI and the controls but they turned out to be my favorite things about SS.

title: Drug Dealer Simulator
comment: No.

title: Carrion
comment: The monster and the audio design are great, but the level and puzzle designs are not. Doesn't help that there's no map screen so a lot of time is spent wondering where to go.

title: Tenchu: Stealth Assassins
comment: Terrible camera, tiny draw distance, clunky controls. Even if the music is fine and the grappling hook is neat, I don't have the nostalgia to tolerate this.

title: Tenchu 2: Birth of the Stealth Assassins
comment: Seemed like a slight improvement, but not big enough to make me want to deal with the clumsy bossfighs and the insane negative feedback loops deaths cause.

title: Freedom Fighters
comment: As neat as the mission structure is, it doesn't salvage the terrible gunplay and appalling AI. The combat gameplay just doesn't cut it for how much of it there is.

title: Hitman 2: Silent Assassin
comment: As much as I like this, the AI has some big issues and a lot of the missions feel buggy. The atmoshpere is still great and even among the good missions there's lots of variety.

title: Budget Cuts
comment: Most of it was okay aside from the movement mechanic and VR in general making it hard to stay oriented, but many objectives were needlessly confusing and the cheating final boss was absolute trash.

title: System Shock 2
comment: The RPG mechanics only get in the way and the combat is terrible, I can't think of anything I prefer in this compared to SS1. I'm sure it gets better on later playthroughs but I don't want to do another one.

title: Until You Fall
comment: 1v1 is really fun, but 1vX is just miserable at least with a limited play space. The weapon upgrade system also promotes grinding over informed decisions.

title: Amnesia: Rebirth
comment:
At best the atmosphere is as great as ever, but it was let down by the writing. Overly talkative protagonist, hard to follow plot and a big cast of faceless characters just did not work. Needlessly linear as well.

Update: The more I think about this game the more I dislike it. Just about every aspect of it was a mess.

title: The Equinox Hunt
comment: Good premise, but sadly the gameplay is extremely basic and there's not much challenge. The prowler is an enemy type that does not belong in a stealth game.

title: Penumbra: Overture
comment: As long as you pretend there's no combat the atmosphere is very good. Overall better than I remembered and I do recommend this, though it's hard to say how well it holds up for a blind playthrough.

title: Penumbra: Black Plague
comment: More memorable moments than Overture, writing ties nicely into Overture and Clarence is great. Less atmospheric to me (probably because I know BP better) and the story nosedives at the end, but I still really like BP.

title: Dishonored: Death of the Outsider
comment: It's more D2, which is fine but a bit uninteresting. Was hoping for something more original like A Crack in the Slab. Outside of the ending it at least handles non-lethal options better by not having assassination missions.

title: Tom Clancy's Splinter Cell: Double Agent
comment: Excessively linear and scripted as SC is, but also very clumsy because of PS2 controls. At least it had a couple of decent missions and a nice gimmick with explosions causing power outages.

title: I Expect You To Die
comment: I can't believe I wasted a perfectly good evening on this trial and error exercise.

title: Hitman: Contracts
comment: The best rating system in the series, the best disguise system in the series and a great mix of missions. Despite some bugs and oversights, definitely in my top 3 stealth games of all time.

title: The Evil Within: The Assignment
comment: Linear and basic, but pretty enjoyable thanks to pacing and atmosphere. Points for above average stealth bosses and making a stealth DLC for an action game, no points for the action stuff towards the end.

title: The Evil Within: The Consequence
comment: See The Evil Within: The Assignment.

title: The Room
comment: Clumsy hidden object game disguised as a puzzle game.

title: Deus Ex
comment: Really liked the music, exploration heavy maps and augmentations systems. Gameplay was generally alright, but didn't excel at anything in particular. Wish it was shorter, the second half didn't live up to the expectations set by the first.

title: El Hijo: A Wild West Tale
comment: Didn't do much for me as it seemes to have been aimed more towards kids, but that doesn't excuse the issues with unresponsive controls and poor mouse support.

title: The Curse of Monkey Island
comment: Looks and sounds good, the writing is good and the nostalgia and remembering many solutions made me accept the insane adventure game logic. Good times.

title: Tom Clancy's Splinter Cell: Pandora Tomorrow
comment: It played to its strengths in the train mission, but for the most part it's yet another linear and unmemorable Splinter Cell. And it has a hilariously dumb ending.

title: Monaco: What's Yours Is Mine
comment: Nice that it has open levels, multiple characters and items that seem to open a lot of different options, but the hard to comprehend art style completely spoils the game for me.

title: Metal Gear
comment: Doesn't exactly hold up well but these days it's mostly a curiosity anyway. By 1987 standards it's probably great, but I could really do without the adventure game logic.

title: Hitman: Absolution
comment: It's generally pretty alright if you don't compare it to the rest of the series. Run for Your Life is easily the highlight as it is a brilliant stealth mission that deserves way more recognition than it gets.

title: hexceed
comment: It's a Hexcells copy so it's at least okay, but sadly this one is quantity over quality so there are a lot of puzzles that take a lot of time despite not requiring much thinking.

title: HITMAN 3
comment:
First impressions video:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wM2vfcfKmMo

title: Metal Gear 2: Solid Snake
comment: Possibly the worst game I've ever played. Being able to go prone doesn't make this an improvement over MG1 when everything else is worse and the game has no no respect for the player's time, at all.

title: Disjunction
comment:
Review video:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8lIgMu30Mrw

title: Volt Patrol
comment: Stealth driving is a fun idea, but it's a small game with not much to it. Mouse based camera controls and better sound effects would've helped.

title: Metal Gear Solid: Ghost Babel
comment: Definitely the best MG up to that point, actually empasizes stealth and the cardboard box feels useful. Sadly the bosses are terrible, at least on Very Hard, Normal is probably a better difficulty overall.

title: Outer Wilds
comment: At worst it's slow and aimless and boring but trying to change that would also spoil the good parts. I expected this to be best played alone without any information or distractions but in hindsight I think the best way to play would be to play with a friend so you can see each other's screens, share discoveries and plan the exploration together.

title: The Operative: No One Lives Forever
comment: I typically go for stealthy approaches, but the stealth in NOLF was really lackluster and far less enjoyable than direct combat. When played as a shooter it's a very standard early 2000s shooter in the style of RTCW or Red Faction, not remarkable but alright if those kind of shooters are your thing. Humor rarely landed, seems the game doesn't have any comedic timing and every joke gets drawn out for far too long. The same could be said about the game in general, the missions and the cutscenes between them often outstayed their welcome.

title: Full Throttle Remastered
comment: Sadly didn't live up to nostalgia the way Curse of Monkey Island did. I still had a pretty good time, just not as good as I had hoped. Also a shame the remaster didn't improve the framerate, the fast sections are headache inducing.

title: The Elder Scrolls V: Skyrim
comment: If this was actually good it wouldn't be nearly as entertaining. But in all fairness, illusion magic does feel original and is really fun to use.

title: Deus Ex: Invisible War
comment: Technologically it's a mess and in just about all other aspects from level design to music it's a huge step back from the original Deus Ex, but the narrative is where it really collapses. It feels like bits of the script were cut out at random, making every character and plot point lack context and seem insane. Then to maximize the confusion, the broken script is delivered by voice acting that's comparable to text to speech. It's not good, but at least it's not boring.

title: Metal Gear Solid 2: Sons of Liberty
comment:
The first half had a decent emphasis on exploration and stealthily navigating the areas in a way that gave a sense of freedom of approach, but in the second half the focus shifted towards more gimmicky sections, boss fights and excessively long lore dumps. Had the pacing been better the plot could've gotten started sooner and the gameplay could've remained interesting until the end, but sadly that was not the case.

And the controls... Pressure sensitive buttons were a terrible idea and even without them the rest of the controls were often counter intuitive at best.

Despite all that, it was at least fairly unique and I can respect that.

title: Watch Dogs 2
comment:
I was positively surprised by how stealth-friendly WD2 was, and the way it focused on using an RC car to do a lot of the riskier infiltration was a nice twist on the standard line of sight based stealth. Overall hacking things like cameras and vehicles was a nice addition, even if phones were excessively strong as a distraction mechanic.

Writing was also surprisingly fun in a campy way which I wasn't expecting. What wasn't fun were the imprecise controls that often made carefully sneaking around frustrating and the occasional open world padding.

title: Metal Gear Solid 3: Snake Eater
comment:
The camouflage system sets MGS3 apart from other stealth games and I'm surprised it hasn't been copied more often. The implementation isn't perfect as the only reason not to optimize the camo every 10 steps is that between food and healing there's more than enough menuing to begin with, but the idea is still neat and it works well enough.

The camera and controls and vastly better than in MGS2, but still leave a lot to desire. The pacing is also improved, and while the cutscenes take forever there's at least lengthy chunks of gameplay between the movies.

Also The End fight is great, one of the best stealth bosses I've seen.

title: Sly Cooper and the Thievius Raccoonus
comment: Stealth mostly in theme only and generally not my type of game, but it's hard to fault it as the platforming and whatever else it was doing worked pretty well and was varied. What didn't work well were the camera that couldn't be turned vertically and the tedious boss fights.

title: Ico
comment: It's fine as a light, atmospheric adventure and I like how the castle loops around and has a sense of place, but the gameplay holds the game back. The escort heavy nature isn't pushed much and usually Yorda just slows the pace down to a needless degree without adding anything interesting. The slow pace isn't helped by lack of automatic checkpoints, meaning that one mistake could easily lead to losing a fair bit of progress which is not fun to repeat and doesn't fit the general feel of the game. There were also one particularly clumsy section with a couple of very awkward jumps that somewhat soured my mood for the following sections.

title: Untitled Goose Game
comment: It's pretty amusing how the penalty for getting caught is just a minor inconvenience rather than a reset worthy event like in most stealth games. Because of it stealth never feels critical, but it's still generally advantageous which feels like a fitting balance in a something like this. Definitely the best goose game I've played.

title: Shadow of the Colossus
comment: Simple and great idea executed very well. The bosses are varied but are still consistently good with a couple of excellent ones, and the traversal between the fights paces the action nicely. The only real faults I can think of are the clumsy horse controls and some graphical hitches on the PS3.

title: Siren: Blood Curse
comment:
The most interesting idea here was using sightjacking to see through the enemies' eyes and use that to avoid detection, but in practice sightjacking cut both the framerate and the field of view in half, making it really obnoxious to use. It also didn't feel that useful as just as just running or fighting were often more viable options, their downside being having to waggle the controller whenever the enemies caught up.

On the upside, the story and the ending were interesting in an incomprehensible way, the music was pretty good and the missions had a decent bit of variety to them, even if most were short and linear.

title: Tom Clancy's Rainbow Six 3: Raven Shield
comment: I really like Raven Shield, even knowing how massively stupid it is on Expert. Even if it is more of a grind where you hope the AI plays nice and lets you win, it's still a chill game for me. Maybe if I get really bored I'll install a fix for the bank level's annoying alarm and continue some day.

title: The Secret of Monkey Island: Special Edition
comment:
While Curse clearly straight up copied a lot from Secret, it also refined everything from puzzles and gameplay to audio, and it generally holds up better as a result. Secret isn't bad  (outside of a couple of very obtuse puzzles), Curse just happens to do a very similar thing but better.

As for the ""special edition"" part of Secret, it's disappointing. The new UI is a downgrade, the art style is hit or miss and while the voice acting is a great addition and well done, it isn't available when using the original mode.

title: Death Stranding
comment: I was down for a chill walking sim, but Death Stranding just missed some important marks. If the whole point of the game is balancing a large amount of cargo, why is arranging it completely irrelevant due to auto-arrangement? When most of the game is walking from A to B with little happening in between, why is the story told largely in lenghty text logs that you can only read between walks? The walking could've been a lot more interesting if you actually had to care about the cargo setup and had something to listen to while you walk, but instead the potentially interesting part is automated and the storytelling is ruined.

title: The Chameleon
comment: I enjoyed the PS1-style, the music and the story, and those were enough to carry the very short and easy game. Definitely not something you play for the gameplay as there's not a lot to see, crouching as crouching is massively overpowered and you'll mostly get spotted when the AI does something that feels glitchy.

title: Max Payne
comment: Very enjoyable combat once you realize that side rolling is the way to go, great writing, an all around solid shooter. Only major downside is that apparently the dynamic difficulty is glitchy and ends up ramping way too high to the point where enemies with shotguns might as well be wielding snipers, which isn't a great feeling.

title: Max Payne 2: The Fall of Max Payne
comment: Still one of the best shooters out there, though coming into MP2 right after MP1 makes the gameplay feel a bit more simple as bullet time replaces side rolling as the primary strategy.

title: Condemned: Criminal Origins
comment:
I didn't expect much but the AI really impressed. The hobos tried to stay hidden and prepare surprise attacks, but also often started infighting after accidentally hitting each other. The levels could be described as very cramped and linear, but the way they looped around and were set in dark and seedy dumpsended up turning that into a positive thing. The audio was also very atmospheric.

What wasn't great was the final chapter. That's where the linearity became too apparent and the combat got repetitive, and the last fight especially was an unenjoyable difficulty spike because of the arena it was set in.

title: The Darkness
comment: The story seems somewhat interesting and the gameplay is okay, but the PS3 version is just terrible. On top of clumsy console controls you've got very low resolution with no AA to speak of and unacceptably low framerates.

title: Saw
comment: Surprisingly decent gameplay and janky in an entertaining way, but unfortunately starts to drag on and repeats the same few puzzles too many times.

title: Day of the Tentacle Remastered
comment: Could be that I remembered a lot of the solutions from 15+ years ago, but most of the puzzles seemed to follow a twisted but understandable adventure game logic which is always good. The time travel plot was also nice as it made for some good puzzles and kept the game world pretty small and contained. Would rank this above Monkey Island 1 and Full Throttle, but below Monkey Island 3. Good remaster too.

title: Metal Gear Solid 4: Guns of the Patriots
comment:
Well, it controls better than the previous entries... Unfortunately that doesn't make the gameplay very interesting. The section where you sneak through an active warzone sound interesting in theory, but in practice it just feels messy as the battle doesn't progress until you move, which makes the whole thing feel very inorganic. The octocamo somewhat fixes MGS3's camouflage issue of encouraging changing camo all the time from a menu, by automatically switching to a perfect camo when you stop moving. Not having to open up a menu is nice, but being able to use a perfect camo pretty much constantly is ridiculously strong and ends up taking away from the stealth gameplay.

The story is like fan fiction trying to bring back everything from the previous games, and considering the ludicrous amount of cutscenes it's shocking how slowly it moves. It wasn't until the end of Act 3 that something actually interesting happened, and the rest of the game never lived up to that. Most of the game relied on nostalgia and tried to build on that rather than actually doing something original.

Also the constant framerate issues and poor audio balancing in cutscenes should not go unmentioned.

title: E.Y.E: Divine Cybermancy
comment: It's memorable for sure but it'll take some time to process how I actually feel about it. Nonetheless, the visuals, sounds and gameplay were all very good, dialogue and world are positively weird, and the story is interesting, if barely understandable. As for actual bad stuff, the lack of proper objective log made some missions needlessly obtuse and some of the later missions were too large for their own good especially when going for the true ending.

title: Silent Hill
comment:
Wasn't expecting the visuals and audio to hold up so well in a PS1 game. The way the fog and the darkness lower the view distance adds to the atmosphere and looks better than most PS1 games, and the soundtrack is great and the directional noise the radio makes avoiding enemies more interesting.

One thing I appreciate a lot is the map/level design, while the game was ultimately very linear it managed to disguise that a lot of the time by having a larger map that you had to explore to find that correct linear route. It didn't always work in the interior areas but added a lot to the exteriors.

Some of the puzzles sadly didn't hold up as well, I think I got lucky with some of them but I can see people getting stuck on them for hours if their brain doesn't work exactly like the designer's. The (bad) ending was also very abrupt and didn't live up to the rest of the game.

title: Metro 2033 Redux
comment:
Definitely not for me. I don't like the feeling of being tunneled towards the one and only path, and Metro takes linearity to a whole new level by often arbitrarily killing you if you try to deviate from the scripted sequence. I first attempted to play on the Ranger mode, but the game was clearly not designed with that in mind as disabling hud also means that you can't tell when you're in a cutscene and when you have ""control"", as in you have to mash a key to not die.

Sneaking is perhaps the best part of the game, but even that is rudimentary at best. Combat on the other hand is just weak, largely thanks to the poor audio design that makes it very easy for rampaging mutants to sneak up on you without making a sound before their attack lands. Plus, the aiming is less than great as horizontal and vertical mouse sensitivities are different and the game doesn't allow changing that. Isn't that exactly the kind of thing ""Redux"" should fix?

At least some of the environments looked pretty good.

title: Prey
comment:
Prey has possibly the best designed game world I've ever seen. On one level there's a whole space station and it's exterior, and on another every NPC has at least a name and a workplace and often much more than that. It's the little things like being able to read the same email from the sender and the receiver's workstations that make the world so believable.

Within individual areas the gameplay is very emergent and exploring is rewarding. Personally I'd prefer the resource management side of things to be a bit less 'shooter' and more like 'survival horror' as even on Hard ammo and health were never really an issue but that's a minor thing.

The one real issue I have with Prey is that the microgravity sections are considerably worse than everything else in the game. Almost all areas are filled with really good signposting and storytelling, but somehow all that is way worse in the microgravity sections. They were the only times where I enabled objective markers and that's saying something.

Still, a damn good game and a worthy System Shock successor.

title: Fallout: New Vegas
comment:
(This was without any mods). Basically everything about the gameplay is so extremely clumsy that it's just not very fun, be it combat, stealth, conversations or any sort of menuing. I can see the open world exploration being the appeal for most people who like this, but I find the post-apocalypse setting is just really dull and colorless so it didn't really invite me to go explore.

I was on board with the main story until all of a sudden it asked me to go meet with a bunch of random factions I had no immediate interest in. It could've been cool had I ran into those factions naturally beforehand or had the option to ignore or meet them, but being forced to interact with them was the worst of both worlds - it sucked the fun out of both aimless exploration and the focused main quest. At that point the main story seemed to completely lose focus and I struggled to maintain interest.

Perhaps the side quests and the DLCs are better, but when the gameplay and the main quest don't convince me, I'm not going to go out of my way to play more. Especially when my brief visit to Old World Blues also left a bad impression with it's unfunny humor and repetitive quests.

title: DEATHLOOP
comment: I just got too bored to continue. The enemies didn't put up any sort of a fight, the main story seemed to be heading for one single solution, and the world lacked the detail I had hoped for. Still having Prey, the better immersive sim, and Outer Wilds, the better timeloop game, fresh in my mind didn't help either.

title: Aragami 2
comment:
While I like the movement and overall gameplay and it looks and sounds nice, it is a bit ""standard"" compared to Aragami 1 and the mission design is a huge issue. The game has more than 50 missions in about 10 maps, and in practice some of those maps are revisited up to 7 times in different missions. I'm generally all for reusing areas assuming there are sufficient enough changes in them between missions, but the changes in Aragami 2 are fairly minimal and the mission objectives are very unimaginative. The vast majority of the missions boils down to finding 4-7 key items or NPCs on the map, dealing with them and leaving. Even if the maps weren't repeated, the objectives would get very, very repetitive.

I do hope there's DLC in the future, as the gameplay is good but it's largely going to waste with the main game's repetitive and overly long campaign.

title: Cruelty Squad
comment: This must be some collective joke that I'm not in on.

title: Intravenous
comment:
Likely the most hardcore stealth game in a very long time, to its own detriment. I'm typically up for a good stealth challenge, but I found Intravenous on True (""original vision"") difficulty to be too hard to be fun more often than not. I really like how mechanically dense IV is but too frequently it felt like the enemies had the advantage, even in situations where it's just one hostile and I had the element of surprise. Perhaps on Normal or even on Easy the game would be more fair and in turn much more enjoyable, but True is just too much.

Massive respect to the one-man-team behind IV in any case for sticking with their vision, listening to feedback and quickly reacting to it and even committing to adding mod support and a level editor later.

title: Dagon
comment: It's a better way to experience the short story.

title: Outer Wilds: Echoes of the Eye
comment: At best it offers nearly the same sense of discovery as the main game, but at worst it resembles cheap Unity asset flips dangerously closely.

title: The Evil Within 2
comment:
Creative enemy and environment designs, paced like a roller coaster ride, intense encounters, solid stealth, action and horror moments. Most of Evil Within 2 is very good and it rarely stumbles, but somehow I think it ends up being less than the sum of its parts. It's like some key component is not quite there, and it could be that the messy story doesn't do a great job gluing the parts together.

It's still good, very good even, but looking all the individual pieces it could be more than that.

title: War Mongrels
comment: Seemed like an okay stealth/tactics game, not on the level of Desperados 3 or Shadow Tactics but clearly borrowing a lot from those. Didn't finish not because the game was bad, it was just not a fun one to stream and likely a long one.

title: Shadow Tactics: Blades of the Shogun - Aiko‚Äôs Choice
comment:
It's a very good expansion, but it's a shame that it's based on the original Shadow Tactics instead of Desperados 3 and thus lacks things like the tactical pause and mission recaps. It's pretty much just ""more the same"" when it's been 5 years and the original was already good, I don't mind at all.

Personally I'd prefer the missions to be about half as long as they are (~2 hours each), but I guess it was to be expected from an expansion. Desperados 3 is still the king of tactical stealth, and I think the next step is to scale the missions down to be less time consuming.

title: GTFO
comment:
(Rundown 6) Bots, checkpoints and actual story missions were a really big improvement after the early access period. The missions themselves aren't very different from the ones in EA so I didn't feel very compelled to do the secondary ones, but the 4 primary ones were all very good and the game still has great atmosphere and visuals, and even with the bots and checkpoints it's still a good challenge.

What I don't like is how the past rundowns still get removed and all the maps from the EA period are now unplayable, but at the same time most of them really weren't very unique to begin with.

title: The Legend of Zelda: The Wind Waker
comment:
Looks and sounds really good, the combat has a lot more to it than I expected and the open sea is one of the rare open worlds that I really like exploring. There's always something new in the horizon to check out but the world isn't overwhelmingly big.

I'm in the minority who liked most of the Triforce quest as well, as it gave me a good excuse to really check everything out. Some bits could've been cut down, like some of the maps feeling like repeats and the deciphering process being completely unnecessary, but it also could've been made more demanding in other ways. The map of maps seemed like a boring way to do the quest and was given very early so I only used it for the last one but I assume most people don't do that and spoil the quest for themselves. The treasures in the sea being indicated with a pillar of light was also disappointing, I think manually comparing maps to find the right spot would've been much more satisfying.

Overall it's a comfy game that moves mostly at a good pace and doesn't demand too much focus from the player. Nostalgia helps too.

title: Northern Journey
comment:
The way Northern Journey balances exploration and retro shooting in a folklore fever dream is unlike anything else I've played. It's also a great example of how a good art direction can go a long way, because of that and the sense of scale in the maps this is probably one of the best looking games I've ever played. 

The only real criticism I have is that some of the levels, especially towards the end, drag on for a bit too long and have a few too many enemies. But that doesn't make it any less wonderful and unique.

title: THE SHORE
comment: It looks impressive both technically and design wise, but sadly there's not much more to it. The story feels lacking, the puzzles boil down to finding what you can interact with, the audio balance is sketchy and doesn't respect the settings, and the ridiculous amount of invisible walls spoil any sense of exploration.

title: This War of Mine
comment: If I'm expected to feel any sort of empathy towards the characters in a game, the game must first get me immersed. If I have to spend the first hour trying to figure out the controls and basic actions, I'm only going to get frustrated instead of immersed. Maybe if there was a short tutorial and it didn't feel like a mobile port there might be something there, but as it stands it was just a miserable experience for all the wrong reasons.

title: No One Lives Forever 2: A Spy in H.A.R.M.'s Way
comment: An improvement over NOLF1 in pretty much every possible way, but the highlights for me were the variety of levels, wittier writing and impressive animations for the time. Stealth was sadly pretty bad and ultimately I'm not too into basic story driven shooters like this.

title: Cold War
comment:
Started off as a surprisingly decent Splinter Cell clone but in the last third devolved into a terrible shooter. The most interesting thing about it is that it made me think how a stealth game could work if it borrowed the map structure and resource management from Resident Evil. 

A large, gradually opening up building to navigate and persistent enemies and gear that you need to carefully manage over time is something I haven't seen in a stealth game, MGS2 being probably the least far off and still nowhere close. And Cold War wasn't very close either, it just had a large building to navigate over several hours, but it was still split into linear levels where areas are arbitrarily locked off and nothing persists between levels even if the areas are reused. But at least it was leaning in that direction.

title: XIII
comment:
I don't normally care much for linear, story driven shooters so maybe it's the nostalgia talking, but I really like XIII. The commitment to the comic book style makes it still look unique and great with all the sound effect texts and picture in picture moments, the guns for the most part feel really satisfying to use and the pacing and the mission/map variety are excellent. And most surprisingly, the stealth sections are actually good which you wouldn't expect from a shooter like this. Good stealth weaponry, stylish footstep indicators and lenient enough AI go a long way.

The only real criticism I have is that some of the checkpoints are a bit too long and at least on the highest difficulty towards the end taking cheap shots from cover becomes too necessary.

title: Tom Clancy's Splinter Cell (N-Gage)
comment:
The N-Gage port of Splinter Cell which turned out to be just a port of the Game Boy Advance version. By far the worst thing are the controls which somehow use most of the 12 buttons available but in the worst ways possible. Running is done by double tapping a direction which leads to lots of accidental sprints and the attack button either melees or pulls out a weapon depending on the context making combat and stealth takedowns very clumsy and unreliable. Instead of dedicated run and melee buttons, we have dedicated buttons for both night- and thermal vision as well as a three buttons that open a menu from which you can switch the vision mode.

On top of the bad controls, there's no checkpoint indicator and the rooms look very, very similar to one another so when restarting it's often hard to tell where you are or what you were doing. The enemies can also see farther than the players which means getting spotted from off screen happens often, unless you're willing to stop and use the sticky camera every five steps. Overall, this feels like half a step above some of those downloadable phone games from the mid-2000s and the physical release feels like a waste of plastic. At least the music was alright, aside from obviously poor N-Gage sound quality.

title: Metal Gear Solid: Peace Walker
comment:
Worst Metal Gear by a long shot. I can admire making something like this for the PSP and remastering it later from a technological and preservational perspective, but the game is still a grindy chore.

Mother Base was a terrible addition that absolutely ruined the pace of the game. I would've liked to see the story through and the main gameplay was okay considering the PSP roots, but the way items and weapons are tied to the base is just a nightmare. When for the 4th time in 8 hours I was forced to manage Mother Base spreadsheets so I could develop required items/weapons and then was forced to do pointless side missions to pass time for the development to finish, I was done.

The comicbook style cutscenes looked neat at least, and it somewhat tried to improve the camo system.

title: Blood West
comment: I like the world design, atmosphere and the fact that the enemies feel threatening and have interesting designs, but something seemed to be missing. It definitely reminded me of STALKER/Thief/Blood/Hunt Showdown, but I don't know if it brought anything original to the table and I hope with updates it starts to feel more original. The stealth mechanics were also pretty unintuitive yet basic. Still, it's early access and I had a pretty good time with it.

title: Thief 2X: Shadows of the Metal Age
comment: No point in discussing the gameplay since Thief 2 is obviously very good to begin with, and Thief 2X doesn't change that. Even if unofficial, it's a great expansion that makes good use of the world of Thief with by having a good mix of different types of levels from horror to steampunk, and the levels live up to the Thief 2 standards, one or maybe two misses aside. I especially like how almost every mission felt distinct and stood out from the rest, which is something Thief 2 struggled with.

title: The Marvellous Miss Take
comment: For such a short game, it's still about twice as long as it should be. The gameplay is good and simple, but the levels don't have anywhere near enough variety to carry the full length of the game. Visually they all look the same and most of the main character's levels do a decent job introducing new ideas, other levels are a slog. Every map has a variation for all characters, and 2/3 variations tend to be repetitive and pointless, yet mandatory to a degree. If the side characters' missions were actually optional I'd like this a lot more.

title: Demon's Souls
comment:
Compared to Dark Souls, there are some parts that are clearly worse like the limits on inventory capacity and the entire healing item system, but in the grand scheme of things that's stuff's pretty irrelevant. What makes me prefer DaS1 over DeS is that the interconnected world structure is just much more interesting compared to the more level-based one. I do however vastly prefer the DeS structure over what the poorly connected worlds later Souls games went with, and it's also what makes DeS stand out from the rest. Also while the quality of the bosses was all over the place, most of them were very different from one another which I like a lot. What I didn't like a lot was that the runbacks to attempt bosses again sucked exactly as much as expected. Taking it slow and fighting enemies is interesting when you're first exploring the areas, but having to deal with them in order to get back to a boss repeatedly is just a bad time.

Either way, not as good as Dark Souls but different enough in a good way, and better than the sequels. Also the second half of Tower of Latria is amazing, one of my favorite areas in the series.

title: The Dark Mod
comment:
I hate to say this about a fan project, but I honestly don't get the point of this when Thief fan missions exist. The stealth mechanics, movement and AI are all clunkier than in Thief, and all that was very apparent trying this soon after Thief 2X. The custom missions are obviously a big part of the appeal, and what the four missions I tried seemed to have in common was huge size, high loot requirements and a low amount of interactable objects, a combination which meant that I often found myself needing more loot and ramming my face into every surface and mashing the use key until I accidentally found something that could be picked up or used.

I will shoutout the mission A House of Locked Secrets though, it had a creative setup and a well executed gimmick that I'm not sure would be possible in Thief. It also helped that it took mostly place in an open ended area and had no specific loot requirement but instead focused on varied story objectives. It was very long like the other missions, but it felt like there was constant progress rather than just spending forever scouring every corner. It alone might make The Dark Mod worth trying, but personally I'm not going to dig any deeper for more gems like it when the other three missions I tried were less than enjoyable.

title: Harvester
comment:
Had Harvester come out today, it'd be another indie game trying to be weird for the sake of being weird and I'd ignore it without another thought, but having come out in the mid-90s adds another layer of weird that's probably the biggest curiosity the game has to offer.

As a game and not a relic from the 90s, Harvester is not very good. The puzzles aren't great, the things you do to advance the plot don't make sense even in the game's context and the last third just drags on unnecessarily. The individual characters, the voice acting and FMVs are entertaining, but that's about it.

title: Iron Lung
comment: Is what it claims to be and makes the most of it. It's a one trick pony, but the trick is good and only lasts an hour so I'm all for it. My only nitpick is that there was one moment where an effect looked pretty bad, possibly due to a too high field of view.

title: King's Field II
comment:
The interconnected world is neat especially for PS1, it's nice to have a variety of weapons and spells that don't just make each other obsolete and I like the way different in game maps have details in different areas.

But unfortunately just about everything else has aged like milk. The combat feels like being a tank  that's trying to perform melee attacks with its turrent, the areas often lack any identifiable landmarks and consist of 1-2 textures making navigation awkward and visuals ugly, and making progress is usually a matter of random exploration that doesn't feel like progress as it's not clear what you were trying to accomplish in the first place. What finally made me quit was a boss near the end that was not only a ludicrous difficulty spike but also required clearing a boss rush just to try again.

title: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King
comment: I might've avoided some frustration since I had a decent idea on what to level up and remembered how the game works for the most part. Didn't stop me from struggling with some of the early missions either way, and one mission with instakill moments was particularly annoying. Either way, it's an legitimately fun action game that from what I recall gets much better in co-op. The level select with multiple paths was also a nice little touch, but it's a real shame you can't revisit levels until after beating the game. I can imagine getting screwed over by making bad skill choices and being unable to level up further.

title: Volume
comment:
Simple gameplay and short MGS VR mission style levels, but stays interesting by doing a very good job introducing new mechanics and ideas at a fast and constant rate. As far as short and simple indie stealth games go, definitely one of the better ones.

The only major issue I have with it is the music, which is unremarkable ambience when in stealth but the moment you get spotted switches to a very loud track that works as a jump scare every single time. Would recommend muting the music and putting on Deus Ex/System Shock/Hitman Codename 47/Prey soundtracks which are more fitting anyway.

title: Quake
comment: It was alright, I just don't feel too strongly about boomer shooters in general and the levels never stand out to me. Too many cheap ambushes to my liking.

title: Hexologic
comment: There's some decent logic puzzling to it, but due to the limited number of potential solutions it tends to devolve into making educated guesses. Disabling the hints prevents brute forcing solutions, but also means you have to manually count every row after every change which is extremely tedious. Still alright for what it is, beats doing randomized Hexcells Infinite puzzle #726.

title: Parasite Eve II
comment:
- Combat has a decent amount of depth with the parasite energy and weapon upgrades etc, feels pretty original
- I like this sort map design with revisiting areas, though this was extreme
- Enemy designs were interesting
- The first area was pretty good
- Camera was one of the worst ones I've ever seen, constantly hiding enemies in combat
- Final boss was the worst piece of garbage I've seen maybe ever
- Some of the puzzles felt really unintuitive
- Could be salvaged with a remake

title: Alan Wake
comment:
- Intriguing story that is unfortunately spread too thin between the action sequences. It still manages to carry most of the game to.
- The gameplay gets very repetitive very quickly. The expansion episodes have some new ideas that the main game could've used, but overall the game would be better off being 70% as long as it is.
- More great Remedy/Poets of the Fall musical collaborations

title: Alien: Isolation - Crew Expendable and Last Survivor
comment: Couldn't remember all the mechanics after not having played the original in years, but still this didn't live up to my memories of the main game. Each DLC felt very insubstantial and linear.

title: Alone in the Dark
comment:
- Pretty good soundtrack and some great voice acting
- Nice variety of creatures
- Trailblazing tech for the time, and considering its age it doesn't look terrible
- Worth playing for the sake of seeing how survival horror got started. Though for a game that has aged better, Sweet Home is the superior choice.
- Extremely sluggish movement and combat made navigating the mansion really cumbersome. Especially the running mechanic was unreliable and clumsy.
- The camera was often all over the place, setting the bar for many survival horror games to come
- The puzzles were full on moon logic nonsense and at the end included a potential dead man walking situation
- Horrible inventory management where you couldn't tell how much stuff you could carry or which items were important. That was especially annoying when dealing with books that contained information that you might want to refer back to later on.

title: Amnesia: The Dark Descent
comment:
- Very strong atmosphere
- Great pacing, both in terms of scary/safe and open ended/linear
- Insightful developer commentary
- Very Lovecraft-esque story, down to the writing style. Protagonist only talked during flashbacks which was a nice way to build character and story without spoiling the immersion.
- Puzzles made enough sense, good by survival horror standards
- No separate audio sliders and the dialogue (including the dev commentary) was a bit too quiet. Also no subtitles for the commentary.

title: Call of Cthulhu: Dark Corners of The Earth
comment:
- The Innsmouth section was excellent. Outstanding mix of exploration, investigation, action, stealth and even some shooting towards the end. The atmosphere was top notch, the town didn't feel threatening but unnervingly unwelcoming.
- The sanity effect and the injury systems were neat, and actually made a noticeable difference in gameplay
- Some nice details in the environments and the complete lack of HUD helped to visuals too
- After the Innsmouth township the quality began to steadily decline until it went completely off the rails in the final chapter
- The AI was totally busted
- The story worked up to a certain point. I wish it had been split between multiple characters, Jack sticking around after Innsmouth didn't really make sense.
- Even if the unofficial patch had worked correctly, the cannon section still would've been terrible due to the awful mouse controls. The very end was also laughably bad with 30fps cap and lowered resolution being needed to get through it.
- On rating: The first 4 hours are a 9, the rest are a 6

title: Condemned 2: Bloodshot
comment:
- The combat is still really fun, especially when the enemies start infighting
- Great pacing, switching between being a shooter, brawler and a horror game
- Investigations were a fun addition, better than in Condemned 1
- The weird stuff fit in much better than the in the ending of C1
- Last couple of chapters were a bit weak
- The PS3 port is terrible, and there's no PC port

title: Cold Fear
comment:
- Ship during a storm is a really cool setting for survival horror
- Some pretty original ideas that they tried to use to a reasonable extent
- The most messed up camera/controls system ever, the game couldn't decide if it wanted to have over the shoulder camera or fixed camera with tank controls so it had both and something in between
- Props to Ubisoft for shipping a development build
- Some sort remake/spiritual successor would have a lot of potential

title: Friday the 13th: The Game
comment:
- Tried the challenge mode and made it to challenge 7/10
- My expectations were low but holy fuck did this still let me down
- Trial and error gameplay with unskippable cutscenes, winning combination right there
- Deliberately(?) bad gameplay with slow as hell movement and clumsy/borderline broken grab mechanics
- Very dumb requirements for unlocking missions, needing to get both "never spotted" and "kill everyone" is like something out of Hitman WoA
- Some of the kill cutscenes were amusing the first time they happened

title: Lost in Vivo
comment:
- Great sound design, visuals and atmosphere. Did not rely on jump scares.
- Went in some very unexpected directions that my messed up brain enjoyed
- Up there with No One Lives Under the Lighthouse and Paratopic as far as mindfuck horror goes
- Some technical issues like alt-tab while in fullscreen crashing my entire PC

title: Resident Evil 2
comment:
- It's very much like REmake, just not quite as good. Notably, the police station is neat but the RE1 mansion is better, and the resource management in RE1 is better.
- The A/B scenarios were a very good addition and different enough from one another
- Some great enemy designs, especially the lickers were a good fit
- Often felt like there was no real goal to work towards other than "explore the police station", because that's what you do in a video game. Especially seemed to be the case in the Claire B scenario.

title: Fatal Frame
comment:
- Some creepy ghost designs and other visuals. The grainy, low resolution PS2 look really suits the survival horror genre.
- Combat was interesting and never felt excessive despite numerous encounters. Fights mattered, and I'm a big fan of that. A couple of the fights towards the end were pretty bad, but most of the time combat was well above average in the genre.
- Very good audio, and the directionality of it worked very well when trying to locate ghosts
- "Jump scares" were great, no loud stingers but just a ghost suddenly being near you
- The mansion design was nice, but there was a lot of back and forth especially when the objectives were unclear
- The game tried to offer directions, but when it failed it was easy to get stuck in dumb ways
- The camera and controls were often clumsy and it was easy to get stuck on invisible corners

title: Silent Hill 2
comment:
- Very good atmosphere, everything felt dreamlike in an interesting way
- Had tons of restraint compared to most horror games, no jumpscares and a bunch of lengthy atmosphere building sections
- Good story, but it seems watching a documentary or reading a wiki is necessary to get the most out of it
- Great soundtrack and sound design
- Looked really good on PS2, arguably better than on PC. The grainy, low resolution look was a good fit.
- Camera and combat were pretty clunky, switching to normal early on was the right choice
- Puzzles were better than in SH1, but still had the same problem where you need to think the way the designer intended. This time they made mostly sense to me, but I can see other people getting stuck on them easily.
- Born from a Wish was played on the PS3 HD remaster, holy heck that's a bad port

title: No one lives under the lighthouse
comment:
- Felt a bit too linear at times, but eventually went full weird in a good way
- Relied on setting and atmosphere instead of jumpscares
- Looked and sounded good, especially the weather

title: BioShock
comment:
- The setting is pretty cool and at least in theory much of it can be navigated using landmarks and signs
- Nice selection of weapons, powers and environmental kills that in theory should make for interesting combat
- In practice the combat is often a total clown fiesta where it's hard to tell what the hell is going on and then you die. It didn't help that the enemies were often unnecessarily tanky and had little in terms of hit feedback. Attempting to play on hard difficulty only made it way worse.
- In practice navigating the world relies on one of the worst maps I can recall ever seeing. The rest of the UI isn't much better either.
- The hacking minigame. Oh god the hacking minigame. It could've maybe been fine had the amount of hacking been reduced by 90% and had someone bothered to make sure that the puzzles are actually solvable.
- The sounds were totally busted and it was impossible to properly track enemies around corners using it. This may be a Remastered issue, which would make sense because it's a damn poor remaster.
- Someone should've tried telling Ken Levine that there are other ways of world building besides audio logs. It felt like the game never wanted to shut up and kept throwing unnecessary logs at you, even though it was nearly impossible to listen to them while trying to actually play the game at the same time.
- Terrible ending sequence featuring an escort mission with a kid that never shuts up and a clusterfuck of a boss fight
- If this was to receive a Dead Space -style full remake it could be good
- Calling this an immersive sim is bloody dumb

title: Deus Ex: Human Revolution - Director's Cut
comment:
- Lots of player agency, many ways to approach situations, all the good immersive sim stuff. Hengsha was fun to explore.
- Interesting world/story/missions
- Very good music
- The Missing Link DLC wasn't very good to begin with, and the way it was placed in the middle of the game was terrible
- No way to completely disable the objective markers despite most of the game being playable without them
- Some tech issues, high resolutions were broken because of the bad HUD scaling and the AI seemed to get stuck sometimes
- Boss fights needed to go away
- The "villain" was really underwhelming

title: Half-Life
comment:
- Black Mesa makes for a very good setting, and the story works in service of the gameplay
- The first couple of chapters make for one of the best openings in any game
- For (one of?) the first story driven shooters, really nailed down how to handle telling the story. The control never being taken away from the player didn't feel like a gimmick and worked great.
- The soldiers not reacting to getting shot made them less fun to fight. Other than that and the weapon balancing, the combat was pretty good.
- Xen sucks hard

title: Quantum Break
comment:
- Poor performance and weird visual issues
- Awful controls, automatic crouch/cover system never felt good, movement was sluggish, getting stuck on things happened constantly, only one slider for mouse sensitivity but two different sensitivities in game
- The game loves to take control away from you all the time, be it the camera turning on its own or losing the ability to lightly jog
- Mixing game and TV show was never going to work, but I guess it was ambitious of them to try. To be fair the TV show part was much better than the game part, maybe as a short series rather than a game this could've been good.
- The TV show portion is streamed from Microsoft's servers so it's a single player game where you need to be online to watch cutscenes, and those cutscenes could be taken down any moment

title: MDK
comment:
- Pretty unique
- Very repetitive gameplay, like if Serious Sam only had one boring weapon
- Bad sound mixing and audio in general
- Sniping controls made sniping inconvenient as you couldn't move and aim at the same time in a decent way
- Stylistically felt like a directionless acid trip
- Nothing related to the plot was explained in the game itself

title: Blood Omen: Legacy of Kain
comment:
- Nice art style that made the most of what PS1 could do
- Good audio, especially the voice acting
- Decent variety of items/spells/equipment that added variety to the combat
- Excruciatingly slow, be it the movement speed, load times, or changing equipment. Guess that's at least partially on me for playing the PAL PS1 version.
- The areas didn't really stand out from one another and often went on longer than they needed to
- Puzzles and dungeons often lacked cohesive solutions and boiled down to "walk through room to unlock another one" or "press buttons until door opens"
- Quality FMVs and lore

title: Gothic
comment:
- Really good lore and setting
- Unique and functional control scheme
- Everything felt simplified to a fitting degree (only one slot for armor, very few stats, reasonably small world, no lengthy exposition dumps)
- Level ups and gear upgrades felt like they were making a significant difference and you were getting stronger
- Janky as hell, both in good and bad
- Lots of time wasted on traversing the world, another fast travel point would've been nice
- Individual quests were often pretty lackluster, either they felt unfinished or too video gamey. While the overarching story was good, the moments in it felt mediocre
- Combat was alright, but fell apart when fighting groups of enemies
