- An hour in a blacksmith glitched out and showed me a vision of what was going to happen 24 hours later. Peak Jank.

title: Hollow Knight
comment:
- The movement and combat feel very good, it's especially nice how much destructible stuff there is to whack when just moving around
- The art style and audio make for a gloomy but comfy atmosphere
- The amount of backtracking and retracing steps is absurd. Since you can't mark points of interest on the map in an intelligible way and new areas are only drawn when resting, you end up checking the same places over and over. Which wouldn't be so bad if you could reach those places in an efficient manner, but there are only a very limited number of fast travel points that tend to be on the far edges of their respective areas, some areas have very limited paths to get around, and once you realize you've come to the wrong place there's no quick way out like a homeward bone.
- I can't stress enough how much a better fast travel system would improve this. It would remove hours of repetitive traversal from the completion time and make exploration way more fun.
- From what I've gathered, there appears to be some really intriguing optional stuff for people invested enough in the gameplay. I only got the basic ending and couldn't say a thing about the lore, but I got a lot of respect for any game that has the guts to hide seemingly significant chunks of itself behind obtuse, secret stuff. If I was more into 2D platforming I could see myself being very into what HK is doing.

title: The Legend of Zelda: Majora's Mask
comment:
- The recompilation port and the tech behind it are the definition of black magic. No issues anywhere, and incredibly easy to use.
- Great setting for the story, the moon crashing in three days is easily my favourite Zelda premise
- Loads of similarities with OoT, meaning the the exploration and core gameplay loop are fairly simple and satisfying. Also meaning that occasionally the progression was somewhat obtuse.
- Stone Tower was probably the best dungeon+boss combination in both this and OoT
- The transformation masks were a good addition, but their movement based skills were too clumsy to control for some of the more precise sections
- The bomber's notebook/sidequests were mostly interesting to explore, but the notebook itself was an awful tool for tracking anything and at worst gave misleading hints. Kafei in particular can heck right off.
- Timeloops are cool and all, but this desperately needed a better way to control time to avoid spending minutes at a time waiting and doing nothing
- OoT is probably the better game on a first playthrough, but MM is the one I'd rather replay as the second time through it's easier to avoid mistakes like deciding to do Kafei's quest

title: Onimusha: Warlords
comment:
- Looked and sounded good
- The combat was fun despite being for the most part very simple. It seems there is a lot more to it than initially appears but the special moves and parries and such seemed very inconsistent to perform. Maybe the manual explains that stuff? Framerate issue? Skill issue?
- Puzzles were pretty alright, aside from the sliding tiles
- Good pacing with the two characters and almost no backtracking despite the singular location
- Short and sweet

title: Pony Island
comment:
- Interesting for what it was, did not overstay its welcome
- Went meta a bit too soon, didn't get a chance to establish what's "normal"

title: Mundaun
comment:
- Interesting art style and atmosphere, felt very original
- The main areas were enjoyable to explore, decently open and the right size
- Some really bad technical issues, like trying to rebind keys softlocking the game and main menu using all GPU power it could
- Clunky gameplay and enemies that were not very fun, feels like this would've been better off as more of a walking sim than trying to be something horror-ish

title: Nioh
comment: Played up to Nue. Getting constantly one shotted isn't fun, limited healing items isn't fun, and the mission based structure isn't interesting enough to deal with the not-fun.

title: Dark Souls
comment:
- Game is still great
- Really good world design
- Painted World and New Londo were the high points, Lost Izalith the low point
- Enemies are actually fun to fight because there are not 50 at ones and they don't have 30 hit combos that instakill you
- A lot of the stuff is needlessly obtuse, especially all the NPC questlines
- Why is everything so blurry?

title: Spy Fiction
comment:
- It's like Swery wanted to make a Metal Gear game, and do it better than Kojima
- At it's best it's amazing, at it's worst it's terrible, could rate this anything between 4 and 8
- Some absurd difficulty spikes
- Pretty neat ideas regarding stealth (camo near walls, disguises from pictures) but ultimately the execution wasn't there and often the stealth just wasn't fun

title: Aragami
comment:
- Great art style and soundtrack
- Blinking around is a lot of fun and works well with both ghosting and more aggressive playstyles
- Objectives were kinda repetitive but the level designs made up for it
- The Nightfall DLC felt like it was designed primarily for co-op with how much more difficult it was than the main game

title: Assassin's Creed IV: Black Flag
comment:
- Looked pretty nice
- Some of the stealthy bits that didn't involve tailing people were kinda amusing because of the oblivious AI and extra strong murder grass
- Ship combat was terrible, incomprehensible and worked as a roadblock as it expected you to have ship upgrades
- Very clumsy controls and movement
- Way too much nothing going on with all the tailing missions, pointless sailing and cutscenes, normal and interactive

title: Betrayer
comment:
- Great sounds and visuals, made for an excellent atmosphere that reminded of the movie The Ritual
- Did very little to explain even the basic concepts of the story which made things unnecessarily hard to follow and grasp
- The basic gameplay was fine, but got very repetitive and it felt like exploration wasn't being rewarded as things needed to be done in a specific order

title: Commandos 2: Men of Courage
comment:
- Played the remastered version, spent 1h in the tutorials and 2h in one (1) mission
- Aged like already slightly rotten eggs, to able to follow Shadow Tactics this was in need of a full remake rather than a simple remaster. Convoluted controls where almost every small action required either its own hotkey or Ctrl/Alt/Shift as a modifier, clumsy camera controls, extremely lacking object highlight options, and tutorials that missed a huge amount of key mechanics.

title: Death to Spies: Moment of Truth
Desperados III: Money for the Vultures
ECHO
comment:
- The gimmick of enemies copying your actions and reseting periodically was an interesting gameplay twist and solved one of the more difficult problem a lot of stealth games have by giving the player a good path to recovery without it being free of consequences
- The HUD-sphere was a pretty good way to indicate where enemies were
- More challenging than most stealth games
- Terrible storytelling, endless exposition filled walk-n-talks. The first 45 minutes were especially bad.
- Environments looked nice, but were repetitive. Abstract mazes don't make for interesting objectives in the long run.

title: Invisible, Inc.
comment:
- Turn based tactics is a pretty original take on stealth, and it works pretty well
- Difficulty felt pretty nicely balanced based on the two runs I did, both runs were very close to a disaster but still made it all the way
- Compared to Into the Breach, the undo mechanic was terrible and the UI was not as clear as I would've liked, led to a lot of mistakes due to misunderstandings. In general there's a lot of mechanics to learn, and you only learn them through mistakes.
- I'm not into roguelikes enough to keep going after 2 runs, it didn't feel like there was a hook like in something like FTL. Feels like I saw everything already.

title: Little Nightmares
comment:
- Very nice looking art style
- The gameplay lacked agency and at times was heavy on trial and error
- I suppose it's okay for what it is, but it's not for me

title: Robin Hood: The Legend of Sherwood
comment:
- Like Commandos and Desperados, extremely clunky and mechanically poorly aged
- Maps are much smaller and missions easier/shorter than in Commandos/Desperados and that's only a good thing in this genre
- The environments look good, but often end up making important things hard to see
- I like how it reuses maps in multiple missions, but unfortunately a lot of the missions feel very linear and devolve into big man with a stick knocking everyone out in 1vX combat
- The forest missions and much of the camp are unnecessary filler and there's a ton of it
- The combat is amusing when it functions, but too often you end up not being in control of whether you're in combat or not, and that makes it a horrible experience

title: Serial Cleaner
comment:
- Pretty stylish
- The viewcone system is really bad. Enemies turning in a frame without warning is not fun to deal with, and as a result this can be very punishing in a way that doesn't feel fair.

title: Shadow Tactics: Blades of the Shogun
Sir, You Are Being Hunted
comment:
- Novel concept, okay for one short playthrough
- Nice to see foliage based stealth that isn't just standard murder grass, even if the execution was a bit shaky
- Procedural generation didn't add anything, the different biomes didn't feel different enough and the areas didn't feel worth exploring
- Got repetitive pretty fast, gameplay was all about looking for smoke while wandering around mostly aimlessly
- Could've used more tools, the only thing I got any real use out of was the bottle

title: Sniper Elite 4: Deathstorm and Target: F√ºhrer
comment:
- The Deathstorm missions were way too long for their own good, but Target F√ºhrer felt like a Hitman mission, as in short and replayable. TF was much more enjoyable in general than the 3 DS missions.
- Sniping while considering wind, distance, etc is neat. Shame the game rarely gives a good chance to make the most of it.
- The AI was way more punishing than I remembered, and not in a good way. Enemies were extremely sensitive to reacting any sort of tiny noise and then immediately spread that reaction to everything anywhere close to them.
- Terrible difficulty system that has a ton of customization but doesn't elaborate on any of the settings or inform you that Authentic is practically unplayable without knowing the mission beforehand

title: Vampire Rain: Altered Species
comment:
- Feels like someone in charge had a vision of how this was supposed to be, but failed to communicate that vision to anyone else
- Surprisingly large and open-ish levels, but often still completely linear and nonsensical. It seems the devs knew that and tried to use weapon pick ups as waypoints to guide the player.
- The story was okay, and turned into fun schlock towards the end
- Ripped off Splinter Cell in a lot of ways but ripping off the always awful control stick angle based movement speed was a terrible mistake
- Most of everything was kinda rubbish, but not terrible enough to ruin the basic functionality
- So many pointless cutscenes, often literally a few steps from one another
- The significance of the frozen wine eludes me

title: Prisoner of War
comment:
- Different kinds of stealth, such as hiding in darkness during the night and undercover during the day
- Surprisingly open ended missions that allowed using those different stealth mechanics freely
- The schedule system with morning/evening roll calls added an interesting time pressure
- So many wonderful accents
- I'm a sucker for reusing locations in different ways, and while 5 escapes from 3 prison camps doesn't sound like much, it was plenty
- Terrible camera, unresponsive controls, often tedious trial and error gameplay, unusable map, awkward analog walking system. The only polish this game has is the one meant for your boots that you wear on your face.
- The final level was a drop in quality, too much hunting for items in unclear areas and repeating similar sections

title: Tenchu: Wrath of Heaven
comment:
- Actively encouraging a lethal approach was a nice change of pace
- Levels felt like they had enough different paths to stay interesting to navigate, and it seems the levels get reused efficiently with different characters and layouts
- Nice variety of missions and enemy types
- Music was good
- Big step up from the PS1 Tenchus, framerate and draw distance actually existed
- Simple but kinda interesting rating system, encourages stealth kills but also makes ghosting viable for the best rating. "Spotted" was pretty poorly defined though.
- Nothing spoils a game like a terrible camera and Tenchu's camera is a disaster
- No checkpoints but plenty of instakill death pits means there's a ton of boring repetition
- Clunky controls and combat, I don't think I ever successfully landed a jumping stealth kill
- Seriously, the camera completely ruins the game

title: Light
comment: Very simple and basic top down stealth game. Could've been fine for what it is, but in a game like this the AI's unreliable behaviour is a critical flaw.

title: Filcher
comment:
- One of the rare games that goes for the sounds/shadows stealth of Thief, and does it mostly well
- Pretty good level design with different paths and a nice variety of locations
- No mid-mission saves meant that a small mistake could be very costly and not in a fun way as you'd just end up repeating the exact same steps. I like having some limitations to saves to avoid save scumming, but this was not the right way to go about it.
- Sound propagation didn't quite work in all situations, especially foot steps on metal were always very loud and it was practically impossible to tell which way people were moving or where the sound was coming from
- I appreciate the fact that there was a rating system and that it was explained, just a shame the stealth portion of it was very binary

title: Metal Gear Solid V: The Phantom Pain
comment:
- Gameplay was mostly great, lots of tools/AI interactions/mobility
- Open world made for some interesting moments with weather/time of day/enemy behaviours, but it also added tons and tons of helicopter rides and pointless walking. Terrible tradeoff overall.
- The story had a couple of ideas, but was ultimately very disjointed and lacked any sort of pacing, especially in chapter 2
- Missions having opening credits that spoil the missions themselves is laughably stupid, but including level designers and writers in them is neat
- Most things in the game added nothing of value. Mother Base, side ops, most "story" missions, Kaz's never ending monologues... Ground Zeroes was the way to go, keep it simple.
- It's pretty shocking that a game can have this much stuff in it but still feel so hollow and unfinished
- Hideo Kojima's MGSV, a Hideo Kojima game by Hideo Kojima

title: The Beast Within: A Gabriel Knight Mystery
comment:
- Really cheesy and fun acting
- Pretty interesting story, it was cool how it tied the werewolf stuff together with real history, even if the history lessons were a bit dry sometimes
- Not a lot of pixel hunting or moon logic, but a fair bit of having to complete things in an arbitrary order
- Almost all text was voice acted which was a big plus in a game with so many books/letters/notes/etc
- Some pretty dumb logic issues towards the end

title: INFRA
comment:
- The first few hours were very comfy and had interesting and nice looking environments to explore
- Taking pictures was fun as it made me pay more attention to my surroundings
- The longer it went on, the less interesting the environments got, the dumber the puzzles got and the more linear the game got
- And it went on for a LONG time, could've easily cut multiple chapters, especially the chapters where you were trying to get to places and took the most insane possible routes
- The story completely lost focus after a while, what the heck happened to the uranium??? Or the accident cover-up??? Why was I not able to tell anyone about this stuff?

title: Monkey Island 2 Special Edition: LeChuck's Revenge
Sherlock Holmes: The Awakened
comment:
- Sherlock versus Cthulhu is a really good idea
- Some of the lore/backstory was interesting
- The puzzles and the plot points often made no sense, even if Sherlock claimed it was all logical
- Not as insane as Mystery of the Druids, and not as coherent as Gabriel Knight 2, in a way fell short in both ways

title: The Dig
comment:
- Looked and sounded nice, decent atmosphere
- The story had some promising ideas, but characters kept making really bad decisions
- Traversing the world felt needlessly slow, especially towards the end
- Moon logic is to be expected from a point'n'click adventure, but it should still be somewhat grounded in reality. Inventory full of unidentifiable items in an alien world does not work for that and a lot of the puzzles were terrible.
- Most of the time there was no goal to work towards, just aimlessly trying everything on everything. At worst the main character seemed to know why he did a thing even when it wasn't at all apparent to the player.
- At least it was shorter than The Longest Journey

title: The Longest Journey
comment:
- Title checks out
- A lot of the puzzles were either mad moon logic or pixel hunting
- Really slow paced, felt like a lot of the conversations weren't very interactive and were drawn out
- Lots of variety in the environments was nice

title: The Mystery of the Druids
comment:
- Lived up to the amazing cover art
- Halligan drugs a homeless man to steal his money
- Actually kinda logical puzzles?
- Pixel hunting which made a walkthrough near mandatory
- Runs like ass on modern systems, including a broken puzzle
- The Ultimate Druid Experience

title: Call of Cthulhu: Shadow of the Comet
Silent Hill 3
comment:
- It's a lot like SH2, but more or less worse in just about every regard. Story, combat, camera, areas... it's "fine".
- The pacing was pretty bad, especially the first few sections and later on a part that was rehashed from SH2

title: Silent Hill 4: The Room
comment:
- Really interesting premise and overall a good story. Definitely more intriguing than SH1 or SH3.
- The apartment has a great atmosphere, the PS2-limited art style with all the graininess works in its favor
- The gameplay is ass. Somehow the combat feels worse than in the previous entries, and there's way too much of it.
- Most enemies were just annoying, whether it was because there were too many of them, or because they were unkillable, or just bland. The twin victims being the exception in terms of design.
- The second half is just awful. I can see how it could work in favor of the story with the unique ghosts, but the areas weren't interesting to explore the first time around so revisiting them is a chore.
- The apartment and the story carry this pretty hard. I'd be lying if I said this was enjoyable to play, but the positive parts left more of an impression than the negative ones.
- This is the SH that should get a remake. This one would need pretty significant changes to reach its full potential, whereas SH1 and SH3 mostly hold up as they are. Stealth gameplay needed to make the ghosts better and scarier enemies.

title: Deus Ex: The Fall
comment:
- Like Human Revolution but with the scope reduced by 80%
- Mouse controls felt bad, often dropping inputs in the menus and having an awkward sensitivity
- Very stiff animations and voice acting
- Considering it's originally a mobile game, it felt like it was still intended to be on a proper platform
- A story about drug monopolies is something that could be told in Deus Ex, but maybe this wasn't the best possible take on it

title: Tenchu 2: Birth of the Stealth Assassins
DUSK
comment: My new favorite boomer shooter? The weapons, enemies, music, and styles were all very good, but the level design is what impressed me the most. A lot of the maps had a strong theme going on and were structured in a way where a map was never needed but it still felt like exploration was happening.

title: Frostpunk
comment:
- Lovely commitment to dread and misery. The music especially added to the atmosphere.
- Perfect setting for said misery. Most post-apocalyptic worlds have at least some comfortable moments, but extreme cold sucks all the time.
- I somehow got a win on the second attempt, but I can see how it would be very demotivating to lose and have to start over without enough knowledge to avoid making the same mistakes again
- Seems there's a lot of replay value with different campaigns and going for a route that doesn't involve ruling the new world as the God King. Being a dictator was fun though.

title: Killer7
comment:
- The art style was pretty neat, especially some of the enemy designs
- The on-rails movement was pretty unique and worked well enough in the context of the game
- The combat was awful, especially on a controller. Aiming at the weak points feels extremely clumsy and gets old fast. It might've been fine if it wasn't for the enemies constantly respawning.
- Some of the worst bosses I've ever seen. If I ever complain about a boss being bad in any game, please remind me of the brainy men of killer7.
- The puzzles were like something a 6-year old would design. A quiz about posters within the same room was one of the low points. Once I realized that the map gives solutions to some the puzzles before you even get to them they got a little more bearable.
- The map was vital for making progress, but it also failed to mark the player location or connect areas to one another properly, making it frustrating to work with
- The way characters talked was extremely obnoxious. Everyone talks in riddles one line at a time with no way to speed it up. It was a challenge not to zone out whenever the gimp repeated how tight the spot was. This feels like a nitpick, but it was an issue all the way through the game.
- There may have been a seed for a decent story, but the storytelling failed it entirely. The best parts were missions that were seemingly totally unrelated to the main plotline.
- It felt like an artsy student project from itch.io that somehow got released as a full game

title: Haunting Ground
comment:
- Hewie is a good boy and actually interesting to work with
- It's was nice that the enemies felt threatening, but the feeling was spoiled by the frequency and the length of the encounters
- The areas were nicely interconnected a lot of the time, but a lot of the time it felt like the areas were random, non-descript corridors only meant to drain your stamina in chases. Also a lot of seeminly aimless running around while trying to figure out what to do.
- Looked better than I expected from a PS2 game

title: Sekiro: Shadows Die Twice
comment:
- Great combat and most enemies and bosses were fun to fight
- Some of From's best world and level design
- Revival wasn't a complete gimmick and felt sufficiently different from just using the flask
- Actually good keyboard/mouse controls
- Amazing stealth (compared to Dark Souls)
- A few boss attacks seemed to have broken hitboxes or tells which was very frustrating
- I don't have the patience for this type of game anymore, the first hours were miserable and the game only got enjoyable once I started studying boss patterns by watching other people play and looked up locations of items I needed

title: Resident Evil 3: Nemesis
comment:
- The section with the clock tower and the hospital had a nice rhythm to it. It also felt like the only part where there was a real story goal to work towards.
- Maybe has replay value thanks to the choices and somewhat random encounters and resources. But at the same time, the (supposedly with no regard to balancing) random resources seem like a really bad way to handle difficulty.
- Even though in RE1 and 2 you did a lot of back and forth in the mansion and the police station, it didn't feel like you were backtracking. In RE3 almost every section felt heavy on backtracking, especially the streets early on.
- The combat wasn't great, the dodge system in particular was awful

title: A Wolf in Autumn
comment: Gameplay felt like it was all about puzzles based on a bunch of red herrings, while the writing was clumsy with extremely long sentences.

title: Spider-Man
comment: Played with a friend while having some drinks, was a pretty good choice for that. Graphics and controls were surprisingly good for PS1. Nice variety of missions too though there were a couple of awkward difficulty spikes, but alcohol and us only half-paying attention to the game may have been factors there.

title: Devil May Cry
comment:
- Combat was fun, at least for a newcomer to the genre it had a good amount of depth to it
- Held up visually, menus and pre-rendered cutscenes aside
- Lots of variety in missions, be it in length, difficulty, style or quality. Most of them were enjoyable, but sometimes you got a Nightmare 3.
- Seems like a good game to replay after getting good at the combat
- The camera was the strongest enemy, some of the most difficult fights were hard because the camera couldn't keep up
- The yellow orbs were a really dumb way to handle mid-mission checkpoints
- Getting the final weapon kinda messed with the weapon systems by removing quick switching and by being too similar to one of the old weapons
- Could've done a bit more to teach some basics, I did not have a manual and tips from the chat definitely helped a lot

title: OverBlood
comment:
- Pretty good story
- Jankiest controls in a good while
- Decent puzzles, aside from a few pixel hunty exceptions
- Saving anywhere was surprising for PS1
- RIP Pipo

title: God of War
comment:
- I started on hard. It was a mistake. The first 50% were pretty enjoyable, would've rated this 6-7 based on that. The following 25% were tedious and frustrating. For the last 25% I switched to easy because there was no option to switch to normal. Even on easy the game was still tedious at that point.
- The stuff with the difficulty modes definitely soured the game for me, with hard being bullshit, easy being tedious and there being no option to switch to normal
- The combat started off pretty good, but as the game went on enemies got tankier and started appearing in giant, respawning mobs and having attacks that could interrupt you without warning
- Platforming and climbing were clumsy
- Due to the tanky and respawning mobs, got very repetitive as it went on. Could've used more bosses or anything to mix things up more.
- Crunchiest sound quality in a long while
- Visually pretty nice, especially for the PS2. The cutscenes in particular were stylish.

title: The Spy Who Shrunk Me
comment:
- Competent, basic line of sight based stealth with a good shrinking gimmick. Being able to hide in corners felt original, though I think the shrink ray's ammo system could've used some more rethinking.
- The AI pathing was very rough, but at least you could work around it by listening for sounds and hiding behind almost anything
- Checkpoints were pretty poorly placed at times
- Has the NOLF-like charm to it, especially with the (repetitive) enemy banter

title: American Theft 80s
comment:
- It's like they learned nothing after Thief Simulator
- All they had to do was take the base idea of Thief Sim and open it up a bit, but they did the opposite and made it more tedious
- What an awful lockpicking minigame, felt like threading a needle
- Terrible UX all around
- Thankfully cheating infinite money was easy, that likely removed a lot of the grind

title: Operation: Tango
comment: Expected it to be more of an open ended stealth thing, turned out to be closer to KTANE. Good nonetheless.

title: Pok√©mon Emerald
comment: It did an adequate job at passing time, but even though it's been a solid decade since I've played any Pokemon, this still felt stale. Would be nice if the most obvious, efective and least grindy strat wasn't leveling up 1-2 pokemon from the start.

title: DOOM Eternal
comment: Probably the most shooter than has ever shootered, maybe a bit too shooter for me. Excessive in every way. Gameplay loop is great and the environments look amazing. Went for all collectibles, even though having to redo the levels from beginning just for one missed secret near the end sucks.

title: Metroid Fusion
comment: Basically improves on all the things I didn't like about Super Metroid, but at the same time over corrects by making the game feel more linear. Every time I got a new ability and wanted to go check out a previous area that I remembered, I could get maybe 2 rooms farther before hitting another wall. Exploration just didn't feel that as rewarding, but other than that it was a straight up improvement from SM.

title: CIA Operative: Solo Missions
comment: Trash, race with Shrimp and oasiz at ESA22.

title: Game of Death: Bloody Infidelity
comment: Mildly amusing Iranian trash at ESA22. Teh best quality modern game the best game.

title: Metroid: Zero Mission
comment: Storytelling went back to being completely lacking but this time with arbitrary map markers. The bulk of the game wasn't very memorable (the repeated Brinstar/Norfair in particular could've been toned down), but the final stretch was pretty good as it changed up the pace and gave some good goals to work towards. It's also getting kinda impressive how consistently bad boss fights in this series are.

title: Super Metroid
comment: Exploration is fun, but overall the game just felt aimless. Open ended goals are generally good, but in this case I never really had a clue  on what to do to make progress and just went wherever I could, occasionally finding an important item from a ditch somewhere. The gameplay and especially movement also got more and more clumsy and annoying towards the end. It's alright, but definitely hasn't aged as well as its reputation implies.

title: Castlevania: Symphony of the Night
comment:
- Much better than Dawn of Sorrow in every aspect. Not being restricted to the DS made a noticeable difference in everything.
- Really good soundtrack
- Great art style
- Movement feels clean and polished
- Just flows very nicely, the progression feels smooth outside of one dumb and poorly translated moment

title: The Dark Pictures Anthology: Man of Medan
comment:
- Mildly amusing at times, maybe for the wrong reasons
- Really clunky gameplay killed any chance of getting immersed
- Full of cheap jump scares
- A lot of uninformed decisions, not just whether the thing will work but what the thing is even going to be
- Unsatisfying ending
- Could've worked as a movie with a proper, cohesive narrative but trying to shoehorn that into a game with a branching storyline was just a mess

title: Sneak King
comment: It's astonishing that a game can be this slow, repetitive, long, and boring. Not even a good meme.

title: Wario Land II
comment: My nostalgia was satisfied. I like the variety of levels, the branching story and fact that you can't die so I can feel less bad about my platforming skills.

title: The Thief
comment: This is not a video game.

title: The Legend of Zelda: Ocarina of Time
comment:
- The PC source port is excellent, there's no going back to N64's low resolution and framerate and limited controls after this
- The first child section felt a little mundane, but that in a way worked in the favour of the later parts as it helped make the stakes feel higher when things started happening. It got the player accustomed to the world and added weight to the key events.
- One gamey ass game, the dungeons felt very much like puzzle compilations that require just enough thinking to get through rather than actual temples. Not a good or a bad thing, it worked for the gameplay as long as you didn't think about it too much.
- Sometimes the progression was a bit obtuse and required seemingly optional things to get done, and Navi as a built-in hint system was useless. Would've been interesting to be able to play this truly blind to get a truer view of some of the sections.
- The combat and the targeting system in particular were not great
- Ganon's Castle's first area and the associated dungeon item were really poorly handled

title: Evil Dead: A Fistful of Boomstick
Jak and Daxter: The Precursor Legacy
Grim Dawn
comment:
- Brain goes off and mouse goes clickclickclickclick
- Unbelievably easy and repetitive, the different quests, areas and enemies made no difference as everything was solved by moving forward and one shotting everyone
- RPG elements stopped mattering after the first couple of hours, after that a level up meant improving the skills alredy chosen
- Items went from "Club" to "Superior Scrapmetal Blunderbuss of Thunder" in about 2 hours which made finding new gear way less exciting than it could've been
- Only played this because I was sick and wanted to play something that didn't require thinking or skill, so I guess I got what I expected. Just to an extreme degree.

title: The Legend of Zelda: Twilight Princess
The Legend of Zelda: Skyward Sword
Gloomwood
comment:
- Nice atmosphere and visuals and audio
- Level design was promising, plenty of different routes to take
- Very light on content
- AI felt a bit uneven, they had very good vision but were almost deaf
- Dogs continue to be not a fun enemy type

title: Tom Clancy's Splinter Cell: Chaos Theory (N-Gage)
comment:
IGN: "Gameloft is one of the few developers that really knows how to squeeze a good performance out of the N-Gage -- and it's never more evident than in Splinter Cell Chaos Theory, a fully 3D actioner with stealth elements that ranks among the system's best titles. The game mirrors its console counterparts so well it's scary -- this is a remarkably complete game on a system full of half-baked ports."

CT on N-Gage: 7 frames per second

title: Cryostasis
comment:
- Body/room temperature mechanic was an original way to handle health
- A couple of neat sections like some stormy exteriors and the movie theatre
- Good setting with the nuclear icebreaker
- Repetitive combat that started off promising but quickly declined
- Flashbacks got very tedious and had too much trial and error in them
- Story came across as pretentious or nonexistent
- Felt like it had the pieces to be a mix of Condemned and Obra Dinn, but wasn't very good at being either

title: Vampire: The Masquerade - Bloodlines
comment:
(Played with the unofficial patch, without restored content)

- Really good cast of characters, the writing, the voice acting and the animations made it a joy to interact with them
- Most of the quests were unique, well paced and had interesting locations
- Gameplay was more basic than in something like Deus Ex, but it didn't feel like a hinderance
- Surprising amount of clan-specific dialog for the Nosferatu, it was fun to see people's first impressions
- Main quest felt somewhat linear and I don't think it needed to, a few lines of dialogue could've made a big difference
- Very good music, though the audio balancing was a bit off at times
- When the quests were bad, they were borderline unplayable and somehow that was most often a thing in the combat heavy main story quests (sewers, Sabbat hideout, final stretch)
- In combat, skills/attributes/whatever felt useless compared to disciplines
- General early Source engine jank, especially if there were physics objects on the ground
- A bad build can be a death sentence and it might be too late by the time you find out

title: Necronomicon: The Dawning of Darkness
comment:
- A funny cutscene or two. The credits techno song is a banger.
- Terrible puzzles consisting of moon logic hints for dev logic solutions, trial and error, and mazes
- Lots of reading with barely legible font choices. The contents of the texts weren't much better either.
- Awful audio balancing with no subtitles
- Somehow even the movement was just barely functional, it was very hard to keep track of which way you were facing

title: Saw II: Flesh & Blood
comment:
- Pretty much everything is bare bones and pretty bad, but mostly not in a frustrating way but in a slightly funny way. Especially worth mentioning are the combat QTEs and the traps where the victims had no control over anything.
- Some of the puzzles were actually quite good for a game like this

title: Call of Juarez
comment:
- Ray is the best character and his voice acting is great
- Dual wielding a revolver and a bible is brilliant
- Surprising amount of mechanics for what seems like a generic linear shooter
- Some of the levels went on for a bit long
- Not enough variety in bible quotes

title: Blood: Fresh Supply
comment:
- Levels flow nicely and I like how they often have a sense of place and connect to one another
- Good setting and style
- Lightly Broiled felt comparable to UV in Doom which is good, I don't think dealing with all the hitscanners would've been fun on a higher difficulty
- The limited enemy/weapon variety made the first two episodes pretty weak. Episode 3 on the other hand was far better than any of the other ones, both in terms of setting and gameplay.
- Doom 64 is still my favorite of the few boomer shooters I've played and I don't really get the hype around Blood as whole, but episode 3 is maybe my favorite set of levels in these games.

title: Deus Ex GO
comment:
- The puzzles are pretty decent, most introduce new ideas even if the difficulty curve is all over the place
- Only one puzzle is available at a time, meaning getting stuck on it halts all progress
- No hint system of any kind, just a solution button that trivializes the whole puzzle
- No idea what the story was about since the UI was broken, making most of the text unreadable
- Touch screen controls suck, even for something like this. N-Gage remains as the superior phone for games.
- Oh yeah the solution system and the undo button are paywalled! Got stuck for the third time? Pay up buddy. Want to continue using the basic quality of life feature of undoing a single move? Better have your wallet nearby. This used to be a paid game too, but I'm not sure if the microtransactions were there back then. Absolute scum either way, even at their best mobile games are terrible.
- I only played this because it's getting delisted entirely and I maintain that erasing games like that is worse than anything this game did, preservation is important. This could've even been a decent game had some greedy executive not been thinking of ways to ruin it.

title: Gabriel Knight: Sins of the Fathers
comment:
- All the 90s point'n'click tropes are here: Pixel hunting, too many similar yet different interactions, clumsy interface, nonsense puzzles
- A huge part of the game was spent doing things that felt completely unrelated to the case, yet were somehow important to progression
- The New Orleans voodoo settings did not interest me as much as GK2's German werewolves
- Even with the big name voice actors it didn't come close to the charm GK2 had with the FMVs

title: Return of the Obra Dinn
comment:
- Interesting story told in an unusual way
- Unique art style that worked very well especially for the characters
- Solving the fates made for a good mystery, but the tools used to do it could've been better. I like bringing out the pen and the paper, but I think some way to tag people ("tattoo guy", "dude with books") would've been nice for example. I also feel like I ended up abusing the way the game confirmed the guesses and solved a lot of "unsolvable" fates early on, which kinda worked as part of the puzzle but also felt a bit cheap.
- The way the progression works is not well communicated and made for a very frustrating first hour when I didn't understand it, and even later on it felt unnecessarily tedious. At times it even felt like pixel hunting was involved, which is why I got stuck and solved an excessive amount of fates early on.

title: Hitman Sniper: The Shadows
comment:
- Made it almost halfway through chapter 2 out of 6 before hitting the point where I could no longer continue without either grinding or doing multiplayer crap.
- It's possible the menus were broken because I got the feeling that the game was definitely designed with microtransactions in mind with all the grindy and lootboxy trash, but the store only used in game currency and the button to buy more of that led to the same page, making using real money impossible. I guess I'll take that as a positive thing?
- Sniping inherently requires a lot of precision. Touch screen controls are inherently imprecise. Playing it is like trying to thread a needle while wearing mittens. The concept was broken from the get go, it just isn't fun to play.
- Mobile games are the worst trash there is but like Deus Ex GO, this should still be preserved

title: Super Mario Sunshine
comment:
- Didn't want to think, didn't have to think. Nostalgia received.
- Levels are proper open areas which I like compared to Galaxy which bored me horribly
- Manta ray boss was pretty cool, used the game's mechanics well
- I wonder how many people had to say "this is okay" for the chuckster secret to get included

title: The Quiet Man
comment: I'm proud of Square Enix for publishing this piece or art in the year of our lord 2018.

title: Nobodies
comment:
- Murder scene cleanup is an interesting idea for a point-and-click game
- Being split into chapters made each puzzle nice and self contained
- Looks pleasant enough
- Kinda clumsy controls
- Most of the puzzles felt really convoluted and not in a fun way. It really kills the puzzle when you spend a lot of time trying to accomplish something arbitrary for an unknown reason before even figuring out what you're trying to do. The first puzzles were fine, but the longer it went on the worse it got.

title: Dungeon Keeper
comment:
- Still looks really good, thanks to great sprites holding up and KeeperFX making it run at a modern resolution and frame rate
- Some of the best sound design in any game I know of, especially the voice acting
- Unique core gameplay that is fun even for someone like me who doesn't play strategy games
- Doesn't explain many of the mechanics well or at all, sometimes even gives detrimental hints (Blaise End)
- Pretty repetitive, might be better off with a couple of levels cut
- The final three levels are absolute trash that rely on knowing exactly what to do in what order, or you're just screwed. And they took about as long as the other 17 levels combined.

title: DOOM 3
comment:
- Played the original version without the flashlight mod, as some moron intended
- The darkness is overdone to an obnoxious degree and the game loves putting enemies within an arm's reach of you knowing that you won't be able to see them anyway
- Because of the cheap enemy spawns and darkness, probably the highest jump scares per minute ratio I've ever seen
- The combat sucks as the weapons don't have any punch to them and getting hit causes massive screen shake
- It's nice that rooms and characters all have names, not that it really matters

title: Call of Juarez: Bound In Blood
Eternal Darkness: Sanity's Requiem
comment:
- Good story and really good writing in general, even the smallest item descriptions made for a good read
- Combat felt more involved than expected due to the selection of weapons and spells
- The sanity system was a lot of fun even if some of the fourth wall breaking effects hadn't aged particularly well
- Ability to save (almost) completely freely and quickly on the GameCube was unexpected and nice
- Some locations were better than others, but overall I appreciate that they revisited the same locations at different time periods and made them feel different enough each time
- Really dragged on towards the end and had one very questionable boss fight
- Not that atmospheric for a horror game, partly because of the fourth wall breaking and partly because of the save system. Both were still a net positive though.
- Nintendo needs to get their head out of their ass and let Nightdive remaster this

title: Sherlock Holmes: The Awakened
comment:
- Followed the original game very closely, mostly cutting out the dumbest moments and puzzles and replacing them with something more sensible, both tonally and logically
- Pretty janky in a lot of ways, including but not limited to poor performance, clunky controls, unintuitive UI. Hopefully a patch/remaster can happen and some polish can be added, this understandably had a difficult development cycle.
- Better as a spooky detective game than the original, but also less fun with things like breakdancing Holmes and insane Moriarty getting cut

title: Metal Gear Rising: Revengeance
comment:
- Great bosses with good patterns and very good use of a dynamic soundtrack
- Very over the top in just the right way, Platinum understood the assignment
- The combat was fun, but also seemed fairly forgiving. A lot of the time I was just pressing buttons at random and it was more than good enough.
- Too easy? I'm bad at these games but because of the leniency, attack and block being in the same button and a huge supply of medkits I still had to handicap myself pretty hard to get a good challenge. Overall it the difficulty balancing felt off and the most fair and challenging setup seemed to be Hard with the self imposed rule of not using medkits.
- Stick wiggle to escape grabs was either way too precise or just broken, and I had more luck switching to WASD when grabbed than using the stick. It's a terrible mechanic that actively drags down the rest of the combat system and I hope whoever came up with it feels bad.
- The Blade Wolf DLC was pretty bad, and the Sam DLC was pretty good outside of the last boss

title: The Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild
Metal Gear Solid: The Twin Snakes
Hrot
comment:
- The setting and the aesthetic worked nicely together
- Levels were compact and had enough variety and sense of place
- The guns and the enemies were somewhat standard, so the combat was enjoyable but kinda unremarkable
- Scratched the shooter itch, on the same level as Quake and Blood

title: Hitman 2: Silent Assassin
comment: Many of the missions didn't hold up as well as I remembered. This playthrough changed my opinions on quite a few of them. Maybe doing a video review thing in 2028.

title: System Shock
comment:
- The structure of System Shock is still very much there
- Art style was pretty good, with the pixelated close ups
- Cyberspace was better than in the original, but the sections went on for too long
- The music was bugged and at least the combat music didn't work, but from what I've heard it's no match for the original anyway
- Some seriously bad UX decisions such as tooltip location, puzzle lighting and scrap management. The original's UI was excellent once you got used to it, this was mediocre at best.
- Terrible combat with no hit feedback in either direction, especially in melee
- The final stretch was full of awful bosses and big fights, including the anticlimactic SHODAN fight
- The good things were already good in the original. Play Enhanced Edition instead, it's awesome.

title: Layers of Fear
comment: Some fun ideas with the visuals, but they're wasted when the game is as subtle and linear as a haunted house ride. Admittely I played this under very poor conditions for horror, but that doesn't change the fact that it's a walking sim with jump scares.

title: Super Mario 64 PC Port
comment: As a part of a multiworld multi-game randomizer with other people playing A Link to the Past, Hollow Knight, Factorio and Super Metroid. Maybe not the ideal game for this as there are very few blocks and a lot of open checks, but it worked out alright this time. Played with a few PC exclusive enhancements and from what I can tell it all worked nicely, outside of one star not unlocking correctly.

title: Amnesia: The Bunker
comment:
- Excellent lighting and audio design, maybe the scariest horror game I've played
- Loved the structure of the bunker itself, small but detailed
- The generator and the flashlight made for really interesting light mechanics
- Resource management was very interesting as most items had multiple uses. Even bricks were a big thing to consider.
- Terrible, terrible ending in a true Frictional fashion. Most of the game was a solid 9/10 but the ending was a 1/10.
- Load zones didn't work quite as well as one could've hoped for, making the monster work awkwardly
- The monster being on a leash was too apparent and at times made attempts at stealth frustrating, especially since there weren't many hiding places to work with. The monster was also pretty hard to track properly, adding to both the horror and the frustration.
- Insane that Frictional managed to make a full blown survival horror immersive sim after each of their previous games being closer and closer to walking sims
- Might at some point replace Alien Isolation as my go-to example of stealth in a horror game. The stealth was worse but the horror was better.

title: Amid Evil
comment:
- Every episode having a distinct visual style and set of enemies kept things fresh
- The maps felt really grand, like a fantasy equivalent of Doom Eternal's environments
- Sometimes the level design didn't feel like it supported the gameplay, especially the last episode was awkward
- Could've used more weapon variety, be it more weapons, episode specific weapon sets, or more practical alt fires. Star of Torment is a top tier shotgun in any case.

title: Lands of Lore: The Throne of Chaos
Might and Magic VI: The Mandate of Heaven
Aliens versus Predator
comment:
- Really impressive that they managed to have so different gameplay styles and campaigns in one game
- The level design was often obtuse and confusing as the areas looked very similar and the objectives weren't always clear
- The marine campaign was kinda great? Very hectic from the get go and a little absurd in its pace.
- The alien campaign was the weakest. Way too many cheap moments where you took tons of damage that you just had to get lucky to get past.
- The predator campaign was okay. I wish it had been even more of a power trip after playing as the weak xenomorph but it was still fine.

title: Slipways
comment:
- Very comfy and simple enough for someone who isn't into 4X or strategy games in general
- Campaign missions are varied and have decent ideas, but are usually not as fun as just expanding the sector freely
- Many planet types look alike and it's hard to see at a glance where different resources can be produced or used
- Randomness in planets in standard runs is alright, but can get obnoxious with perks/tech and with campaign planet layouts
- The standard mode might replace Hexcells Infinite as my go-to comfy game

title: Amnesia: A Machine for Pigs
comment:
- Writing was very pretentious and thus very funny for the wrong reasons
- The pigs were more cute than scary and never felt threatening
- A couple of pretty neat setpieces, namely the overrun streets and the ending
- "I am a lobster"
- "How can a man shit so much blood and live?"

title: Nightmare of Decay
comment: It's like a more condenced and less stressful Resident Evil with some good laughs. Not exactly original but very cool.

title: Paratopic
comment: Very surreal. Quite confusing. Special thanks to amphetamine. <lie> I don't care about the giant ball of twine.

title: Hypnospace Outlaw
comment:
- Turned a clumsy late 90s computer experience into a unique and interesting game
- Way more realistic than it had any right to be, in a very different way
- Great soundtrack by the earth haze master Zar√©d and some less important artists
- There's something great about looking for illegal download links to music not only because it's your job to take the links down but also because you really want to add the tracks to your personal library
- The endgame was frustrating. Had it been either a hard to trigger post-credits section or less obtuse in general it would've been more enjoyable.
- More linear and mission based than I hoped. It would've been great if it had been closer to Papers Please in how it approaches doing the job of an internet tough guy.

title: Polimines
comment:
- The puzzles are alright, though personally I'm not a big fan of Picross
- The UI needed more clarity, most of the mistakes I made were because the clues were awkward to read
- No music is a big drawback in a Hexcells-like

title: C.H.A.I.N.G.E.D.
comment:
- I really like the idea of multiple developers making a collection of games that are linked to one another, without full knowledge of all other games
- Seemed to have a case of quantity over quality and the quality ranged from nearly unplayable to pretty good
- The branching choices were disappointingly not integrated to the games themselves but to just a menu between them
- Bit of a technical nightmare especially for streaming
- Props to the dev whose game had no gameplay but set the next games up with a golden AK
- Feels bad to be harsh on a community project but it just didn't stick the landing

title: Abermore
comment:
- Probably the most blatantly unfinished game I've ever played, including early access games. Makes Lucius 2 look like finished game.
- It was impossible to take 10 steps without something breaking. Especially the map/mission generation was absurdly broken, building levels with multiple kinds of softlocks and unplayable scenarios.
- The final mission would not load in a playable state 80% of the time and ran at 20fps, forcing me to give up after about 10 attempts
- Feels bad for the devs, this is clearly not what they wanted to release. Then again, it's 20‚Ç¨ which feels like a robbery.

title: Dread X Collection
comment:
- Very mixed bag, some really good stuff but also some really bad stuff that would've been better left on the cutting room floor
- Summer Night, Mr. Bucket Told Me To, Shatter and The Pony Factory were pretty good, Rotgut and Hand of Doom were alright, the rest were not

title: The Residents' Bad Day on the Midway
Sweet Home
comment:
- Good setting, though the story could've been communicated better
- Unique feeling mix of metroidvania, JRPG and survival horror
- The Resident Evil connection is clear with the limited inventory and interconnected map, but since there was no central storage managing items was closer to Goof Troop. It wasn't too bad when referring to a guide, but it would definitely have been annoying to start backtracking for an item you previously thought was useless.
- Menus were pretty clumsy, especially when trying to figure out what weapons to use
- Very easy, the combat didn't have much depth and saving anywhere meant there was no need to take risks. Using a guide surely played a part too, but I feel like it mostly reduced annoyances rather than difficulty.
- Far exceeded my expectations for a NES game. Obviously it feels outdated in many ways, but when played as a handheld game with a guide I had a good time and think it was worth a playthrough just to see some of survival horror's roots.

title: Amnesia: Justine
comment:
- One hit kills and no saves is a pretty annoying combination
- Reminded me of Penumbra Requiem, as in it felt like it was made out of leftover puzzles from the main game
- Probably made more sense as a part of the Portal 2 ARG, on it's own it's not great

title: Baldur's Gate: Enhanced Edition
comment: The storyline didn't feel like it was going anywhere and the gameplay felt very combat focused, which is a shame because the combat wasn't very good. Maybe later on with more skills and spells the fights could become interesting, but when 5 hours in only 2 out of the 6 characters had hit level 2, I couldn't bring myself to continue with the way things were looking. I prefer my combat encounters being rare but memorable, and BG seemed to be going for the opposite. I would much rather spend an hour talking to random tavern goers in Planescape Torment than slaughtering kobolds in Baldur's Gate.

title: Shadow Gambit: The Cursed Crew
comment:
- Probably the best stealth tactics game out there, overtaking Desperados 3. Very good gameplay overall, felt like the next logical step for the genre.
- The characters felt equally overpowered in a good way, all of them had their upsides and it was hard to have a bad team setup
- Mission length and difficulty was toned down compared to other games in the genre, which is only a good thing since these games tend to be very hard and have very long missions
- Because characters could be unlocked in any order and islands were reused for several missions and could be done in any order, there were very few good, memorable setpiece missions that stood out from the rest. In contrast, I still remember a lot of Desperados 3 missions because the environments and team compositions were specifically designed for their respective missions.

title: Synth Riders
comment: It's like Beat Saber except the devs don't break all the modded stuff with every patch.

title: Abandonware
comment: The games themselves weren't anything too exciting but I like the concept. Early access in this case especially makes it feel like it's too early to have any real opinion. I'll keep it on my radar. VOD is only the first hour, I took another look off stream and made some progress.

title: Unsorted Horror
comment:
- Short and sweet little horror games, the art style and the sound design were very pleasant
- The Other Side and Control Room Alpha were very enjoyable, Carbon Steel and Tartarus Engine felt like they could've used more stuff, Concrete Tremor didn't have much to it

title: Devil May Cry 3: Dante's Awakening
comment:
- The combat was improved from the already good DMC1. Styles were a good addition and especially Royal Guard was fun to use, but it would've been nice if switching between them wasn't so limited.
- The additional weapons didn't feel as good as Rebellion, but still had occasional uses. Nevan in particular was unique, but sadly also controlled very poorly.
- Good enemy and boss designs, almost all bosses made for good fights or at least added variety. The only notable exception was Arkham.
- The writing was absolutely full of edgy cheese, in the best possible way
- Dreadful camera. I get that having the camera be close to the action makes everything feel more intense, but way too often the enemies were out of sight.

title: Void Stranger
comment: Off stream.

title: No Sun To Worship
comment:
- Looked nice, sounded nice, controls were snappy
- I can respect a more challenging stealth game and especially on hard this put up a fight
- Mechanically very lacking. No distractions or tools, despite focus on shadows and sounds it mostly played like a line of sight based game.
- Health as a energy resource is a nice idea, but it was only used to avoid sounds which was rarely an issue to begin with
- The hold up mechanic was disappointing as there were no interactions beyond the initial hold up. You couldn't take guns, move held up enemies or efficiently use them as bait.
- The supposed message/theme did not come across at all

title: Payday 3
comment:
- Mostly competent stealth gameplay, with updates and improvements I can see this getting a lot better over time
- Nice variety of different heists
- Most of the cool and unique things about Payday 2 didn't make it in and nothing really new was added. No randomization on reset, no Sixth Sense, worse detection mechanics and indicator, no limit on zipties.
- Crowd control seems to be more about trading hostages and delaying the assault rather than trying to stop the alarm from kicking in in the first place, which is disappointing
- The Hitman-esque challenge/progression system was full of uninspired challenges that were impossible to sift through and sometimes failed to unlock correctly
- The replay value Payday 2 had doesn't seem to be there as there's no randomization on reset and even when you do go through matchmaking for a different seed the differences feel small
- Lots of small issues like poor favor systems, clumsy hacking/mini cameras, lacking audio cues/footstep sounds for NPCs, terrible vaulting mechanic
- Always online. There is no excuse.

title: Thief Simulator 2
comment:
- I'm no graphics enthusiast and had everything set to low, but damn this game looked horrendous and didn't run well either. The lighting in particular was borderline broken, with time of day affecting even windowless rooms.
- The sounds were very bad, walls did not affect sound propagation at all so attempting to track NPCs by their sounds was a total waste of time
- The skill tree and progression system were completely pointless as you had to do almost everything in a very specific order anyway and could only spend skill points in set ways. Cheating to get extra XP and money actually made the gameplay feel a bit less linear and boring.
- The story was a series of unrelated fetch quests with no interesting twists or missions, aside from maybe the heists
- The gameplay was a complete copy+paste from Thief Sim 1, which wasn't great to begin with. Like in TS1, ideas like tracking tenants' schedules were nice, but needed to be way more fleshed out. As it is, this feels like an asset flip of TS1.
- Streamer mode is totally busted and does the opposite it's supposed to do. It replaces the soundtrack with a bunch of poorly fitting Kevin MacLeod (uncredited...) tracks that DO get muted on Twitch, while the non-streamer mode soundtrack doesn't get muted.

title: Kane & Lynch 2: Dog Days
comment:
- Felt a lot longer than it really was, exhausting to play
- Extremely loud despite seemingly missing a ton of sound effects and music
- Ugly for intended and unintended reasons as the camera was never still and the texture resolution couldn't be set above medium without the game crashing
- Was there a story?
- The decision to make Lynch playable made no sense, the one main appeal of K&L1 was that you're teaming up with a loose cannon lunatic. On the other hand switching to Kane for the final mission made no sense either.
- Crashed at least twice in as many hours, and didn't work properly with multiple monitors
- In some twisted way I can respect the commitment to being as obnoxious as possible in every conceivable way

title: The Windows Are Gone
comment: For a while it was going places and had enough restraint at the start to set the mood, but then abruptly stopped after going for horror tropes.

title: How Fish Is Made
comment: No one expects the tongue parasite dance turning into a shameless ad for another game.

title: 50 Flares Deep
comment: Cool idea, doesn't do much but gets its point across.

title: Incident at Grove Lake
comment: Walking sim about aliens. I guess it's fine for what it is, but I didn't get much out of it.

title: Forgive Me Father 2
comment:
- Very good art style
- Shooting was fun, especially the revolver was satisfying to use
- The explosions were extremely underwhelming
- The boss fight was pretty weak

title: Teleforum
comment: Interactive short story, a pretty alright one.

title: World of Horror
comment:
- It's a lovely idea
- I can respect the commitment to the style despite some shortcomings that came with it
- The investigations/stories felt very disjointed and were apparently just flavour text on top of a far less interesting resource management game
- The choices felt very surface level and often disconnected from anything that seemed meaningful
- After seeing the launch trailer, the art was pretty disappointing

title: Dread X Collection 2
comment:
- Much better than the first collection. Overall game quality was higher and the hub area was a good addition.
- Charlotte's Exile, Squirrel Stapler, Sucker for Love and Undiscovered were good. Solipsis, The Diving Bell, To the End of Days and Touched by an Outer God were alright. The rest ranged from passable to terrible.
- Squirrel Stapler being a better stealth game than some actual stealth games was a nice surprise. Great sound design.

title: Unsorted VHS
comment:
- I like Klubnika's style and this had a fine SCP-esque premise, but left me feeling like there should have been more to it
- Compared to Unsorted Horror, this was a big disappointment. The name and the price implied that there would be more than a single short story, but that's all it was. Had it been part of Unsorted Horror instead of being its own thing, it would've fit right in and been one of the best parts.

title: A Hand With Many Fingers
comment:
- Really cool premise to build a game around real world events, digging through archives and connecting the dots between events
- The ending was a bit underwhelming. Could be that I'm just too dumb to see all the implications and REALLY connect the dots?
- More of a narrative thing than a typical game, but also something that would not work in any other medium

title: The Devil Haunts Me
comment: Feels more like a (well put together) demo or a prototype rather than a full game. Despite seemingly discovering just about everything it left me feeling like there was more to it and a lot of things were left unexplained. If there is more, awesome, if not, I'm disappointed.

title: Ion Fury
comment:
- Really detailed and beliveable environments. I don't expect boomer shooters to have any logic in their level design, but it's nice when they do.
- Most enemies were pretty dull and annoyingly often spawned in areas that had already been cleared

title: Squirrel Stapler
comment: Played as a part of Dread X Collection 2, but deserves its own entry so I can mark it as a sneaky game and give it a higher rating. I was not expecting this to be stealthy at all but it definitely was, and the audio was handled better than in many more typical stealth games.

title: Teardown
comment:
- For a game so focused on destruction, a surprising amount of variety in missions. Most were of very high quality too.
- The standard "steal things in 60 seconds" heists tickled my brain the same way routing speedruns does. Encouraged creativity in a similar way that Hitman missions do.
- Looked and sounded good. Some of the best looking snow in video games.
- Impressive tech that handled a ton of destruction even on my old toaster with very few framerate issues
- Intricate maps that were reused appropriately
- DLCs: Art Vandals is alright for a free modding demo. Time Campers is mediocre. Folkrace is bad.

title: Thief: The Black Parade
comment:
- Very polished and complete feeling mod
- Some great enemy and environment designs, especially towards the end
- Large and elaborate missions, clearly meant for more hardcore fans of Thief
- Felt like a Thief Gold mod rather than a Thief 2 mod not just because it was one, but also because the level designs were leaning more in that direction. Personally I didn't like Thief Gold's levels that much, and Black Parade reminded me of those.
- Maybe this was the case in the actual Thief games as well, but the platforming and especially dealing with marble floors was often infuriating. I get that marble is supposed to be very loud and challenging to work around, but guards on the Moon reacting to every tiny step was just obnoxious.
- One of the missions gave me nice Demon's Souls vibes and while not making the most of Thief's gameplay, stood out from the rest in a good way. Could've been shorter though, the second half felt a bit like a repeat of Mage Towers.

title: Blood West
comment:
- Eldritch wild west is a cool setting and the enemy designs were good. Sadly the story or quest designs didn't do much with that.
- The enemies felt threatening and getting past them had tension to it, but the way checkpoints and fast travel worked also meant that dying was very frustrating
- The stealth didn't feel good with visibility and sound being combined into a single system
- The guns felt alright, but didn't seem to do much damage outside of headshots

title: Sniper Elite 5
comment:
- Sniping was great, but as with all games like this there was nowhere near enough of it. The focus was on getting close to the enemies rather than in shooting from afar.
- Maps are large and kinda open, but also riddled with invisible walls and other dumb barriers
- Movement controls were very sluggish, especially the cover and climbing systems were frustrating to work with
- This series is in a desperate need of a reboot. SE5 is mostly good but not the same kind of improvement as the previous instalments have been and there is no more gas in the tank. There's nothing unique about the series as this point and I wish it would fully focus on hardcore sniping instead of being a jack of all trades.

title: Stargate: Timekeepers
comment:
- Terrible performance and full of bugs
- Terrible as a stealth tactics game. The missions are excessively linear, the abilities are bland, the save system barely works and the bugs make the gameplay inconsistent.
- Terrible as a Stargate game. You never go through the gate, the staff weapon is only used for melee, the scientist is an idiot, three shots disintegrates, practically no connection to the series outside of the first mission. Why would you ever have a character called "Sam" who isn't Carter?
- Embarrassingly unprofessional launch. Delaying the release by 5 weeks without announcing it until after the initial release and pretending this isn't early access when the second half of the game doesn't even have a release date should not be acceptable.
- I really like Stargate and I really like stealth tactics games but I really don't like this game

title: Lethal Company
comment: Prime example of a game that's kinda bad but fun with friends. The gameplay loop is very shallow but that's okay because it's always funny to see your friends get eaten by monsters while trying to warn you about nearby monsters. Co-op horror with proxy chat just works.

title: Chop Goblins
comment:
- Kinda adorable, and shooting goblins is fun
- Banging soundtrack
- Jumping would be nice, just because jumping is inherently fun
- It is as good as it aspires to be

title: Milk outside a bag of milk outside a bag of milk
comment:
One of the visual novels of all time. Not sure what to make of it. Or if I'm even in the position to make anything of it.

Played Milk inside... on stream, then decided to play Milk outside... off stream.
vods: https://youtu.be/2KM8lhoc5Bo;Milk inside a bag of milk inside a bag of milk

title: Timelie
comment:
- Pretty alright puzzles. Time manipulation is a nice way to easily try out different things and learn enemy patterns.
- The cutscenes and transitions between puzzles drag on for way too long every time. It feels like a small nitpick, but they add nothing of value and I'd just like to play the game.

title: PowerSlave: Exhumed
comment:
- Original setting and pretty good shooting
- Looks, sounds and plays well
- Missions feel distinct and the way they're connected to one another is neat. Only towards the end the quality started falter due to over reliance on the hover mechanic.
- Unfortunately when missions are revisited they don't feel different from the first time through despite the new abilities
- The checkpoint system is a little rough, but works. I like not relying on quicksaves, though there are definitely unfair feeling moments where a manual save would be nice. Not being able to use the same checkpoint twice in a row also seems odd.
- The random pickups from pots are bad. There seems to be no balancing whatsoever so you might just not get any health or ammo when you need it, and it does feel dumb having to be careful about every pot as you never know if it contains a health pickup or a trap.

title: Papers, Please
comment:
- Checking for papers is somehow really satisfying and engaging
- The small story arcs an events are interesting and fun
- Jorji is an absolute legend
- When restarting from different days is a bit hard to keep track of things
- Achieves exactly what it's going for, while being original

title: Impossible Creatures
comment: Maybe I'm not smart enough for this or this game isn't very strategic. The winning move seemed to be just grinding out the biggest possible horde of wolcupines and have them march into the enemy base in a conga line.

title: Noita
comment:
- The basic gameplay and movement is good even for someone like me who doesn't like 2D platforming
- The perks and spells add a lot of depth and make each run feel different enough
- The wands having tons of stats makes recognizing the good ones at a glance hard. I'm sure that's something that comes with time, but the learning curve feels a bit steep.
- Got my first win after 22 deaths, but apparently there's a ton more to see and I do want to keep playing so I might update this review over time

title: Alan Wake's American Nightmare
comment:
- Combat felt improved, but still not great and was best avoided by running
- The story was weaker than the one in AW1

title: Half-Life: Opposing Force
comment:
- Pretty good selection of weapons
- It's cool that it gives a different perspective to HL1's events, but the story is still bland
- The pitch black section with large aliens was great
- The final stretch wasn't Xen, but it wasn't much better either

title: Half-Life: Blue Shift
comment:
- Yet another perspective on the Black Mesa incident, still a nice way to do expansions
- The only levels that weren't built around an excessive number of crates were Xen. Neither were good.
- No interesting weapons

title: MyHouse.wad
comment: Used its chosen platform of a Doom wad to do something unconventional to near perfection. Pretty skyboxes and a banging soundtrack.

title: Halo: Combat Evolved Anniversary
comment:
- Very good combat in general, thanks to a variety of weapons and enemies. The enemies having voicelines and ragdolls also made it more fun.
- Lots of variety in scenarios, from more linear corridor based combat to large open spaces with multiple factions fighting each other. Even The Library had its purpose, even if it went on longer than necessary.
- Two weapon limit is weapon durability done right
- Good mission/chapter/level titles are underrated, and Halo has some of the best ones. Though I do wish the main titles (not the mid-chapter titles) were more clearly presented.
- I like revisiting levels, but a lot of the levels felt copy-pasted and uninspired
- The original graphics looked generally better than the updated ones, but being able to switch on the fly was cool

title: Portal: Revolution
comment:
Follows the blueprint of Portal 2 very closely, so much so that I'm glad it's been a long while since I last played P2 as otherwise this might've felt too similar. The puzzles are good, the pacing is good, the locations look great, all in all it's an extremely polished mod.

The flaws are also straight from P2. Sometimes the puzzles devolve into "find the portal-able surface", and the sidekick tries too hard to be funny.

title: Hotline Miami
comment:
- Ridiculously stylish graphics, soundtrack and everything else
- Fun gameplay, even if it sometimes feels a bit luck based and I'm bad at it
- Only as long as it has any need to be

title: Last Train Outta' Wormtown
comment: Tremors: The Game. It's a one trick pony but the trick is fun with friends, at least for a while. The balance is pretty busted though with settings needing constant adjustments to avoid one side streamrolling too much.

title: Intruder
comment: Played with friends. Felt a bit clumsy from what I recall, but it was still a decent time.

title: Intravenous 2: Mercenarism
comment:
- Doesn't feel different from Intravenous 1, meaning it's still doing way too much and works as an example of why going for realistic AI in stealth games is not fun
- I can respect the vision, but in practice this is an exercise in frustration
- Not going to play the main game once it comes out, this was enough IV for a good while

title: Hitman: Blood Money Vegas
comment:
- They sure tried to to have some stealth mechanics in a phone game. They weren't explained very well, but sure seemed to be there.
- The main menu music is actually a pretty solid adaptation
- Writing is very not Hitman
- Yeah it's bad by any reasonable modern standards. But I probably would've replayed this for SA in 2006 had I had this.

title: Hitman: Blood Money Reprisal
comment:
- Blood Money is still an outstanding game even if this port isn't
- The simplify strangle setting finally has a purpose, it now makes 47 walk like he pooped his pants
- Generally worse controls and UX, things like picking up and throwing items were unnecessarily changed
- Some small improvements like the minimap and a clearer loadout selection
- Biggest bug I ran into was the parade not working correctly in The Murder of Crows

title: Dead Space
comment:
- A very good but pointless remake. The original still holds up and the remake is so faithful to it that it barely adds anything new to the experience.
- Most of the changes were for the better and I'd call this an improvement over the original, but there was very little "new" to see here
- Weapons were much better than in the original. Each one I used had a different purpose and even the ones I didn't use seemed alright.
- Isaac talking was an unexpectedly good thing. I was initially against it but it wasn't overdone and allowed him to be more of an engineer.
- Flamethrowering the dividers had a real The Thing -esque feel to it which I very much enjoyed
- Zero-G felt clumsy compared to the original, even if it gave you more freedom
- The way the Ishimura was more interconnected than before is neat, but I do miss how the tram bookended each chapter in the original
- The claims of the performance being stuttery regardless of components are greatly exaggerated, the PC version runs fine. The biggest issue I had was being unable to bind "heal" and "skip audiolog" to different buttons.
- The lore and story were made more sensical, but sadly towards the end started to set up for the nonsense that Dead Space 2 requires

title: Undetected
comment:
- The bosses and the writing were funny as a parody of MGS which is already a parody of itself
- Atrocious camera. Why on earth would you ever want to copy the camera from MGS. This could've been a fun little throwback to MGS but the camera ruins it.
- Using the explosives was clumsy, particularly the slime grenade that you're supposed to apply to your feet but have to throw away from yourself first

title: Persona 3 Reload
comment:
- More of a resource management game than an RPG. Even in the dungeon sections managing SP was more important than fighting enemies.
- Very comfy, at least while it still feels fresh. Plays well, looks and sounds great, the combat has the right amount of depth.
- Enough quality of life features that allow even me to get into it. Quick retrys, fast travel, clear and informative UI, tracking of how you're doing compared to other players etc.
- Very easy on Normal. I'm no JRPG person so I didn't want to up the difficulty, but the longer the game went on the less combat I did because it just wasn't challenging and I figured the bosses might be more interesting if I'm a little underleveled.
- It's hard to follow how different stats make a difference to anything as they change so often and the combat is largely focused on using weaknesses. I kept making the numbers go up, but couldn't tell if that was important in the grand scheme of things.
- Way, way, WAY too long. During the first half new mechanics kept popping up and choices had to be made regarding resources, but in the second half the novelty of the combat wore off, resources got maxed out and the daily routines dragged on. Especially around the mid point of the game there was a long stretch where almost nothing was going on.

title: FlatOut
comment:
- Good visuals and destruction, very mid-2000s soundtrack
