- I had a pretty good time overall, but I don't see racing games in general having much long term appeal or lasting impact
- The minigames were fun on paper, but needed more polish
- Some frustrating physics issues where objects seemed to randomly decide to be light or heavy depending on the position of the stars
- For a game about reckless driving, it sure liked to punish reckless driving

title: Scorn
comment:
- All style, no substance. Seems the devs knew what they wanted the game to look like but didn't know how to make it into a game.
- Grotesque imagery alone isn't enough to add shock value, there also needs to be context behind it and there was none to be found. The little story that there was wasn't communicated well either.
- Clumsy combat that was best avoided
- Bad exploration as the areas were narrow, linear, and still hard to navigate due to the low field of view
- The whole last area was a collection of softlocks, bad checkpoints, terrible bossfights and audio bugs

title: Slayers X: Terminal Aftermath - Vengance of the Slayer
comment:
- Fitting Hypnospace spinoff 
- Pretty good selection of enemies and weapons
- Short, but the joke still wore off before the game ended
- Finding where to go was sometimes annoying and that could've been avoided if the maps were more helpful
- The S-Blade has a Hackblood charge!

title: Alan Wake II
comment:
- Interesting mindfuck of a narrative that probably makes more sense on a second playthrough. Or not.
- Does look pretty
- Remedy + Poets of the Fall always works
- Combat still wasn't great, especially aiming the flashlight felt clunky
- Alan's lamp and writer's room were cool ideas, but a bit inconsistent and awkward in practice. Same with Saga's mind place.
- Some video game tropes that really didn't need to be there, like open world collectibles and especially tracking them so the player can avoid missing them. It would've fit better if whatever stuff is in the world is more easily missed or not there at all.
- Really awesome that Remedy got the opportunity to go full weird like this
- Finland. David Lynch. Max Payne. House of Leaves. In the Mouth of Madness.
- Night Springs DLC: Pretty great, especially the Rose episode. I like it when DLC is disconnected from the main game like this. Just let the main game be done.
- The Lake House DLC: It's alright, a Control side story with Alan Wake's gameplay and atmosphere.

title: Cocoon
comment: Clever main mechanic and good puzzles. Minimalist puzzle adventures aren't really my number 1 thing, but this is definitely a good one.

title: Hardspace: Shipbreaker
comment:
- It's a really neat idea that seems like it would make for a comfy and relaxing game but in practice is mostly just slow and sluggish
- The hazards try to add a some variety, but dealing with them is only a minor part of the whole process which otherwise is very repetitive and cumbersome
- The story is told in the most boring way possible, and doesn't seem interesting either
- The time limit in the standard mode doesn't feel like it adds anything meaningful to the game and only serves to add unnecessary pauses to the actual gameplay. Doesn't really fit the universe either, somehow in the capitalist dystopia people aren't allowed to work more than 15 minutes a day.

title: Metal Gear: Snake's Revenge
comment:
- Pretty good music and sound design
- The end sequence was alright
- Not the worst checkpoints imaginable
- The most unresponsive password screen I have ever seen
- Chocked full of very cheap deaths, item farming and equipment shuffling. Instakill pits out of nowhere, entering a room 20 times to pick up items, trying all 8 keycards on all doors.
- Side scrolling sections were almost a nice twist, if only they hadn't been awful every single time
- Despite its reputation, not considerably worse than the MSX2 games. Maybe even sneakier than those two?
- The most bare bones port imaginable (Master Collection), as expected from Konami
- Kojima wasn't involved but shall take the blame regardless

title: The Hex
comment:
- Interesting for what it was, did overstay its welcome a bit
- Went meta immediately, but it didn't really matter. There was no core game that the meta stuff was attached to.
- Pretty crappy art style

title: The Hong Kong Massacre
comment:
- Looked good and clear despite all the debris. The action was fast and fun. The OST had some great tracks.
- Windows absorbing the first bullet that hit them felt dumb. Sometimes the enemies were too far off screen. The perfect aim challenge felt unreasonable compared to the other two challenges. The boss concept was neat, but not neat enough to be worth repeating multiple times. The story was obviously not important but the way it was told was still really boring.

title: Dreams in the Witch House
comment:
- I expected a point'n'click adventure with some survival mechanics but it turned out to be a much more open ended investigation type thing. The closest comparison I can think of is Frostpunk, as in you're working towards vague goals while trying not to be too miserable.
- Great sound design and music
- Maybe the best Lovecraft adaptation? And the most accurate depiction of student life?
- To be revisited somewhere down the line? Seems there's a lot you can't do in a single playthrough.

title: Quake II
comment:
- The levels had a lot more setpiece moments and coherent structure than Quake 1 or most older shooters
- The weapons and enemies were pretty uninteresting. Especially the hitscan enemies and the monster closets got old fast.
- Even a less good boomer shooter is still decent fun
- The updated version is technically very good

title: Taiji
comment: I immediately bounced off The Witness because using the mouse to draw lines felt uncomfortable, and this is a very similar game with no such issue. Many of the mechanics were good and puzzles challenging, but some felt like nonsense even after looking up explanations and I have no desire to go back for them.

title: Portal
comment: Shocking news, Portal is still very good all around. The RTX tech demo Nvidia bolted onto it, not so much.

title: Maid of Sker
comment: It's a horror game where the enemies aren't scary or threatening. That's a problem. There is some gameplay beyond just walking and I like that the mansion worked as a central location.

title: Content Warning
comment: It's fine, but much better on paper than in practice. Lethal Company works because the team has a reason to split up while still working together, and there was plenty of agency on how to approach the looting. In Content Warning you never split up so you always know your entire team's situation, and a good run is more down to enemies incidentally showing up at the right time rather than anything the players can influence.

title: Ereban: Shadow Legacy
comment:
- Competent, but not exciting
- Very easy, even to ghost
- Uninteresting skill/gadget systems that I barely even touched because there was nothing of interest to unlock
- Very reminiscent of Aragami
- One segment with such cringy writing it's noteworthy in itself

title: Shadows of Doubt
comment:
Still needs way more time. Pretty much everything I said in my video about the closed beta still holds true.

https://youtu.be/Nq4GdI_QyRM

title: Voir Dire
comment: Fun little game about packing juries. Each case has its own fitting gimmick and the game makes the most of its ideas.

title: Halo 2: Anniversary
comment:
- It's more Halo. Still has really good pacing and variety thanks to all the weapon and enemy types, factions and various scenarios that mix all of those.
- The updated graphics were generally a step up
- Many of the areas still felt copy-pasted, especially in some of the Arbiter missions
- The story felt rushed. Because of the character swapping it felt like some characters just arbitrarily showed up in placed, and the ending was disappointing.

title: Dread Delusion
comment:
- Really striking art style and chill music made for a nice atmosphere
- Interesting and well written lore, especially parts of the Endless Realm were great
- The loosely structured main quest and the small but dense world made exploring fun and it was easy to get sidetracked in a good way
- Traversing the world was speedy and utilised several mechanics, in part thanks to fall damage cancelling
- Incredibly easy to the point of approaching boring. The combat was never a threat and almost entirely avoidable with no effort, and the quests (while well written) felt mechanically formulaic.
- Despite the exploration starting off great, it got staler and staler as the game went on and the rewards got less and less meaningful
- Awful lockpicking system

title: Buckshot Roulette
comment: Fun little game about playing Russian roulette. Not much to it, but does what it sets out to do. I normally really like Mike Klubnika's art style but for some reason this game screwed with my monitor and made everything look ugly and oversaturated.

title: Flathead
comment: The gameplay is one step above flipping a coin. Maybe there's interesting esoteric bullshit to be discovered, but actually playing the game is just boring.

title: Sonar Shock
comment:
- A+ for the idea of horror System Shock in a soviet submarine
- The level design is pretty nice, if too dark
- Controls much worse than System Shock Enhanced Edition, lack of vertical look especially sucks as a lot of of loot and enemies are below eye level
- Extremely limited healing and hitscan enemies make the combat an exercise in frustration
- Huge performance issues
- Feels unpolished with inconsistent dialogue, bugs and such

(The dev is apparently planning a director's cut patch, so this is on hold until that)

title: A Short Hike
comment:
- Extremely comfy and appropriately low stakes
- Great soundtrack
- Everything feels nice and snappy

title: Nex Machina
comment:
Very much not my type of game so it took a while to get used to the visual business and to get over the Xbox controller's right stick being uncomfortable to hold for extended periods of time. I did enjoy the game well enough for most of it, but the way power ups work sucked a lot out of it.

Experienced mode starting with 99 continues seems like it may as well be infinite, but a single death can put you in a really nasty feedback loop. On death you drop some power ups and then when you try to recover those dropped power ups you die again, losing even more power ups, until you're stuck in a situation where you have nothing left and just die repeatedly due to the lack of both offensive and defensive options. I don't think I ever lost a single continue on my Experienced run, they were all lost in clusters while trying to recover.

That still could've been fine, if it wasn't for the final boss. What an absurd difficulty spike that threw in attacks unlike any other enemy so far, some of which were just about unavoidable without power ups, which I obviously didn't have after the first few deaths. I don't know if this sort of systems and difficulty spikes are the norm in games like this, but if they are, I fully understand why these are a niche thing.

title: Resident Evil 5
comment: Very casual playthrough. We were under the impression that even on Amateur the dynamic difficulty adjust would do enough, but it clearly didn't because everything was very easy all the way through. A very "okay" game overall, with a nice pacing where new enemies/environments/situations were introduced often.

title: Layers of Fear 2
comment: Some fun ideas with the visuals, but they're wasted when the game is as subtle and linear as a haunted house ride. Admittely I played this under very poor conditions for horror, but that doesn't change the fact that it's a walking sim with jump scares and short trial and error monster attacks. Obnoxious writing too, more so than I can recall from the first one.

title: Devil May Cry 4
comment:
- It's good, but not as good as DMC3
- Dante's Royalguard didn't feel as good to use as in 3, but Nero's Exceed pretty much made up for it. Also, Nero had a dropkick. Therefore Nero > Dante.
- Being able to switch Dante's styles more freely was great, but his moveset felt a little worse compared to DMC3
- Devil Trigger is still cheating, fight me

title: 20 Minutes Till Dawn
comment: Building synergized setups is fun at first, but after a few rounds it becomes clear that repeating very similar plans is what works every time and trying to deviate doesn't. Weapon and character differences ultimately don't add up to enough variety and the pool of perks isn't that deep.

title: Halo 3
comment:
- Halo combat is still very good with all the enemy types/weapons/vehicles/etc, and the way they are mixed and matched in different scenarios
- Better level design than the previous Halos, with less copypaste and padding
- The story was messy, it's like you were expected to know the lore without it being properly explained

title: Islands of Insight
comment:
- The puzzles were definitely made with quantity rather than quality in mind and range from "barely functional" to "pretty clever" and with a lot of non-puzzles in between. It's not necessary a bad thing either, sometimes solving a bunch of trivial "puzzles" is what you need.
- The world looks nice which adds to the comfy little-thinking-required puzzles
- The UI is dreadful, bloated, and detracts from the comfy feel. It made tracking things clumsy and made me not want to continue after finishing the main quest.
- The supposed multiplayer aspect adds exactly nothing to the game. At least it's getting an offline mode.

title: Betrayal At Club Low
comment: Interesting and unique and messed up, but I don't really feel like doing multiple playthroughs as so much of is luck based.

title: Nebraska
comment: It's Penumbra at home.

title: Inscryption
comment:
- Cool atmosphere
- Broken mechanics, in a good way
- Minimal UI with diegetic elements looked good
- The early game was definitely the best part, and the later parts couldn't quite live up to it

title: Sewer Rave
comment: Mind altering.

title: Liquidators
comment: Points for the idea and the execution, good stuff considering the scope. Some unclear aspects like how the different characters mattered and were supposed to be managed.

title: What Remains of Edith Finch
comment:
- I'm not big into walking sims, but this was a pretty good one
- They way gameplay and storytelling were mixed was neat
- Some of the controls felt clumsy

title: Sumerian Six
comment:
- Felt extremely close to Mimimi's games to the extent that I though it might be using the same framework (this is a good thing). Not quite as polished at times, but the very fast save/load times make up for it.
- Pretty good set of characters and abilities. Even if I didn't use all of them it wouldn't surprise me if even the "bad" ones could be used in ways I didn't think of.
- Banger soundtrack
- Difficulty balancing was a bit off. Sometimes you could effortlessly clear entirely rooms with a single character, sometimes you needed extra precise timing with the entire team. Might be at least partially an issue with Hard mode where enemies spot you so fast that the setting that slows down time when you're about to be spotted becomes useless.
- The challenges were uninteresting. Getting experience pickups from missions was a good way to make the player explore most of the map, but also in a way defeated the idea of having multiple paths through the maps.

title: Frostpunk 2
comment: Not my thing. The original Frostpunk was great because of its small scale and this seems to have gone in a completely different direction.

title: Castlevania: Dawn of Sorrow
comment:
- I am terrible at 2D platforming and lots of my issues with this game likely stem from my own skill issues
- Exploration was pretty nice, though the map really could have used some way to mark obstacles manually
- Nice soundtrack and art style
- Clumsy combat, not least because of contact damage and excessive knockbacks which seemed to be there mostly as an annoyance. Supposedly it gets better with cancels and such, but I think if those are needed to make the combat good, it wasn't good to begin with.
- Weapon/spell options being so important but also being based on random drops is pretty messed up
- Excellent PC port, especially the ability to rewind is a great addition that helps avoid losing lots of progress due to silly mistakes

title: Ori and the Blind Forest
comment:
- Really good art style and music
- I suck shit at platformers but will say that most of it was pretty good, especially the bash mechanic was fun
- Exploring the overworld for power ups was enjoyable and chill
- The combat was bad and I think the game would be better with far less of it. All the effects and foreground objects making it hard to see what was going on didn't help.
- The second dungeon was the weakest part with an obnoxious gimmick, while the last dungeon was the highlight as it had very little combat and a lot of bashing

title: Lorn's Lure
comment:
- Cool climbing mechanics and overall a fairly original game
- Pretty weak level design. There was rarely a good sense of scale of what was being traversed and some more landmarks could've gone a long way to help with that. The chapters were also like 30% longer than they needed to be.
- It was sometimes really hard to tell where the right direction was and the best way to tell what the wrong path was, was to go in some direction, die, and realize you never got a checkpoint
- The final level could've been good if it was shorter, less full of dumb death traps and didn't rely on a brand new mechanic

title: Mouthwashing
comment:
- Heavy on dialogue with very little gameplay
- Some nice visuals and a couple of interesting setpieces
- Story was alright once it really got going

title: Slay the Princess: The Pristine Cut
A Quiet Place: The Road Ahead
comment:
- Some actually original and interesting stealth mechanics like silently opening doors, managing asthma, avoiding murder grass and the ambient noise system from Chaos Theory
- The stealth arenas were good and had tension to them
- At least as a streamer, mic getting picked up by the game added to immersion
- Very linear and game-y with the most hilarious take on yellow paint (which can be disabled) I've ever seen and an absurd amount of loud stingers for a game that's supposed to be about being quiet
- Uninteresting story
- It's no Alien: Isolation or Amnesia: The Bunker but for a licensed stealth horror game, gets respectably close

title: Halo 3: ODST
comment:
- The team being basically the crew from Firefly was a fun touch
- The Halo combat is still pretty good, even if nerfed a bit by having less variety
- The audiobook in the hub areas was totally unnecessary
- Really ugly compared to the main games. Not only did it go for the brown'n'bloom visuals, but replacing the shield gauge with a bloody screen meant that often during combat everything looked like a mess.

title: Castlevania: Portrait of Ruin
comment:
- More linear than SotN and DoS. Not a bad thing, even though there was less exploration the game also flowed more smoothly. Also no equipment farming that DoS suffered from.
- The art and music are, as expected, a far cry from SotN. It's a shame the series went on only on handhelds.
- The boss fights required for the true ending were irredeemably bad and I'm glad I cheated my way through them. Not worth the effort otherwise. Seriously left a bad taste in my mouth and spoiled the otherwise good game. Could've even been a 7/10.

title: Jazzpunk: Director's Cut
comment:
- Basically just an interactive series of weird gags, but mostly they're actually good. One of the rare games that are genuinely funny.
- The bonus(?) chapter was considerably weaker than the main game

title: Fire Emblem: The Sacred Stones
comment: Most of it is fine or even good, but the random hit and crit chances mixed with permadeath really spoil it for me. I'm sure you're intended to accept some losses, but when one of your stronger units gets killed due to bad luck it's hard to not just get salty and restart.

title: Biped
comment: Really simple but really fun. Takes just the right amount of coordination and is a little clumsy in a funny but not annoying way.

title: We Were Here Together
comment: Pretty good, but I preferred the fairly similar Operation Tango. In comparison the puzzles in this were longer and the workload wasn't always that well balanced between the players.

title: Sorry We're Closed
comment: Didn't resonate with me. Too much dialogue without voice acting between the gameplay sections made me just get bored. The actual gameplay was promising, but I don't think I want to sit through 30 minutes of silent chatter between those sections.

title: S.T.A.L.K.E.R. 2: Heart of Chornobyl
comment: To be continued once it has received some patches.

title: Deadly Premonition 2: A Blessing in Disguise
Limbo
comment:
- Very nice looking art style
- The gameplay lacked agency and at times was heavy on trial and error
- I suppose it's okay for what it is, but it's not for me

title: Unravel Two
comment:
- Very basic puzzles and platforming, definitely gets better towards the end with the last area having the best platforming in the game
- The co-op is undermined by the option to merge the characters so that only one person actually has to do anything

title: Indiana Jones and the Great Circle
comment: To be continued once it goes on sale.

title: The Lord of the Rings: Gollum
comment:
- I went into this expecting a bad stealth game, but there was actually very little stealth and in reality this was mostly a very bad Prince of Persia clone
- I can't emphasize enough how poor the controls and basic movement were
- The little stealth there was was extremely rudimentary
- Bad performance all the way through
- The story was completely pointless
- The spiders could navigate between walls and floors, that's a little impressive
- WHAT DOES "BEASTS" MEAN, PRECIOUS, WHAT DOES IT MEAN??

title: Devil May Cry 2
comment:
- The combat is a shadow of what it was in DMC1, craziest thing about it is that there is no real skill upgrade system
- Lucia was marginally more fun than Dante because her ranged attacks are worse so you have to actually play the game more
- At least it's not frustrating as it mostly plays itself, except when the camera hides important things

title: Balatro
comment:
- At the time of review: 16 wins, 90% collection, highest win on purple stake
- Great as a mobile game, far better than any of the actual mobile games I've tried
- Once it gets going, optimizing the deck is interesting and satisfying
- Like with most roguelikes, the first parts of each playthrough are braindead boring. Especially on higher difficulties.
- Relies too much on luck rather than strategy. Sure you can mitigate the luck factor by going for some safer strats, but that also makes the game more boring. 
- Update, July 2025: The more I play the more obvious it becomes that this would be way more fun if you could just skip ante 1 and start from ante 2 with two semi-random tags. Skipping the first blinds to get tags is the obvious opening play, but some of the tags are just not worth starting with.

title: Brotato
comment: Compared to 20 Minutes Till Dawn, the build variety feels much better. The characters and weapons are different enough from one another to make different playstyles feel worth exploring, and since you can pick a starting weapon and can reroll a lot in the shop it also feels viable to aim for specific builds.

title: Vampire Survivors
comment:
- Really makes me appreciate how much something like Brotato iterated and improved on the concept
- Does get better as more things are unlocked and as you learn (look up) the evolution combinations
- Seems there might be some fairly interesting secrets to be found, I discovered one but lost interest in the game soon after anyway
- The UI is absolutely terrible, not only is it unresponsive but it also hides a lot of the relevant information (weapon levels, evolution combinations) exactly when it would be useful, or doesn't show it at all
- Excruciatingly slow in every regard. Default movement speed, giant levels, excessively long loot animations, and long round time all contribute to this.
- In a typical run, nothing interesting happens in the first 10 minutes because it takes a while to get items, the middle 10 minutes are actually interesting as you can optimize the level ups and have enough tools to actively fight the enemies, and the last 10 minutes are spent doing very little as the items get maxed out and all you can do is wait until the game ends in either victory or defeat. I don't get why the default round time is 30 minutes when so much of it is just boring.

title: Lara Croft Go
comment:
- Only one puzzle at a time means getting stuck is easy, no undo function at all, hint system is locked behind a paywall, the controls are clumsy and unresponsive. The one edge this has over Deus Ex Go is that there is no dialogue that could glitch out.
- The puzzles are okay

title: Dark Messiah of Might and Magic
DmC: Devil May Cry
comment:
- Good combat that required intentionality with a nice variety of weapons
- Platforming was by far the best in the series so far
- Visuals and sounds were fitting and stylish. A lot of distinct looking areas.
- Writing ranged from okay to so bad it's funny. And that's a good thing. I wish it had been more cringy.
- The camera kept getting stuck on things in a really awkward way
- Colour coded enemies hurt the combat by removing most weapon options
- Vergil's Downfall: Vergil's moveset isn't as good as Dante's. One bossfight that's better than the ones in the base game. Sometimes broken in really funny ways.

title: Prodeus
comment:
- The mix of sprites and chunky 3D looks really nice, and the nu-Doom-esque music fits well
- Even though the levels loop around, they feel really linear
- The guns feel good and the combat starts off well, but gets really repetitive before the game is over. The unarmed zombies seem to be treated as a threat despite them being completely harmless.
- Because of the respawn system, dying isn't even an inconvenience, it's a free health refill. There was no tension in the combat as a result.
- Played most on very hard and only dropped to hard at the final level after one attempt, I was quite done with the game at that point

title: Yono and the Celestial Elephants
comment:
- What a weird mix of cutesy art and a storyline about election rigging and existential dread
- The puzzles were pretty easy but not bad
- Side quests did not feel worth doing

title: Half-Life 2
comment:
- Very well paced for the most part, keeps throwing in new stuff to keep things fresh. Even the boat part was actually good. Only towards the end the freedom fighting sections start to really drag on.
- Weapons are a mixed bag. The shotgun and the revolver for instance were good, but the more rapid firing weapons were too inaccurate to be really fun to use. Especially when fighting the tankier Combine soldiers who didn't seem to care about getting hit.
- The flashlight having limited power and also sharing that power with sprinting and diving felt dumb and unnecessary
- While the physics were fun in combat situations with the gravity gun, there were definitely a lot of tech demo feeling moments with the puzzles

title: Half-Life 2: Episode One
comment:
- Yep, it's more HL2
- Pacing is still good despite the unnecessary amount of little cutscenes, but the individual sections are weaker than in the base game. Especially the second half is just forgettable.
- Combat and weapons are still mediocre, but at least there's more focus on indirect ways of fighting
- The parking garage was annoying but in a deliberate way and I kind of like how it's stressful in a different way compared to anything in the base game. Highlight of the episode.

title: Half-Life 2: Episode Two
comment:
- Actually continues the story, unlike Ep1
- Best combat sections in HL2 since it's more focused on close quarters
- Good pacing, and a strong ending fight
- Gnome meme isn't worth it unless specifically doing a second playthrough for it, otherwise it turns the game from HL2 into Gnome Carrier

title: The Stone of Madness
comment:
- The structure might be good? Maybe it's like a metroidvania or a Resident Evil with stealth tactics gameplay?
- The UX is disastrous. Every improvement Mimimi made to the genre over the years was completely ignored, be it basic controls, interactions, highlights... anything. Even Commandos had better UX. There are not even rebindable keys.
- Voice acting, please add some. Especially if you're going to do loredumps.
- It seems the devs had great ambitions but didn't get the core gameplay to a tolerable level

title: F.E.A.R.
comment:
- Pretty good weapons, they got a nice kick to them
- Very little variety in enemies and environments
- The story fell flat, but the premise of the FEAR unit was interesting. Unfortunate that the later games stuck to the Alma storyline rather than doing different things with FEAR.
- It sure is one of the games where you shoot things

title: Overcooked!
comment:
- We first played some OC2 so coming to this it was hard immediately noticeable how controls felt less polished and the gameplay simpler
- It's good for what it is, but all it really has over OC2 is the flamethrower gimmick from seasonal levels

title: Overcooked! 2
comment:
- More polished than OC1, being able to throw ingredients added a lot to the gameplay
- The gimmicks in the base game were generally worse than in OC1, but got better in the seasonal levels. Especially the horde maps stood out as something different, and also as a difficulty spike.
- Both games are good fun in co-op and almost equally good. The reason I think OC2 has the edge is because we started with OC2 and played OC1 between its main campaign and the seasonal levels, which made polish more noticeable.

title: Magicka
comment:
- The spellcasting system is really inventive yet simple. Early on just throwing rocks felt like a solution to everything, but even towards the end whole new spell types kept coming up.
- Funny kind of stupid humor, largely carried by the mangled swedish/danish/whateverish dialogue
- The difficulty spike near the end was a little ridiculous. Maybe it was partially due to only having two players and using controllers, but the sudden amount of instakill situations felt rough. Then again, it really forced us to come up with new strats to survive.
- Needing an unofficial patch just to make the game crash less says something about the technical issues
- After understanding the controls, controlled surprisingly well with a Steam controller

title: Ctrl Alt Ego
comment: Tries to be too smart for its own good and ends up being frustrating. There are some really clever and original mechanics which is why it's so disappointing when they don't come together in a satisfying way and the solution turns out to be "key item blending in with static objects" or "just kill the enemy lmao". Maybe I'm the stupid one, but this did not click.

title: Destroy All Humans!
comment: I got next to nothing out of this. There are a bunch of mechanics that could be interesting, but the missions and gameplay just feel sloppy.

title: Alone in the Dark
comment:
- Interesting story and entertaining writing
- Very average gameplay and sadly quite linear
- Environment and enemy designs were neat

title: Stardew Valley
comment: I have played this game.

title: Pacific Drive
comment:
- Really interesting premise, both for world and gameplay
- Driving through the zone is atmospheric
- Dreadful narrative where characters keep talking while hellbent on keeping the player out of the loop
- UI that feels like it was designed by an early AI mid-hallucination
- In the end lost my interest due to the randomly generated areas and the resource management. On paper making expeditions into the zone sounds great, but because the randomness whatever you discover feels meaningless, and it still pushes you to micro manage the resources which just isn't very interesting.

title: Doom
comment:
- Played the Nightdive remastered version, episodes 1-4
- I was worried that the new soundtrack would sound out of place, but it very much doesn't. Great addition.
- Doom gameplay is still very good, but the enemies and super shotgun from Doom 2 are sorely missed
- You can somewhat tell that this has some horror game roots as it seems reluctant to give you ammo for the bigger guns and scarcely uses tougher enemies. Lots of jump scare -esque monster closets too.
- The level design is... not great. Lots of needlessly maze-like areas and "something happened somewhere" -triggers. At worst said triggers aren't even tied to switches but to walking into some arbitrary spot. Mt. Erebus was the highlight map for me as it was more open than most and had a hefty amount of enemies and ammo to work with.
- It kinda reminds me of Thief 1, which also had excellent gameplay but the level design didn't make a great use of it

title: The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion Remastered
comment:
- Terrible performance and buggy as hell
- There's something really compelling about this type of open world in a generic fantasy land
- The spell system has a nice amount of options, at least when the spells work as they should. Shame that the spellcrafting mechanic requires doing so much of the mage's guild.
- Terrible performance and buggy as hell
- Stealth with invisibility spells is the most broken "stealth" I've ever seen, to the point where it doesn't feel like sneaking
- The main story is pretty decent, especially the premise is good. Does lose steam in the latter half due to fetch quests though. Also the engine clearly can't handle the kind of spectacle the story was going for.
- Terrible performance and buggy as hell

title: Doom II: Hell on Earth
comment:
- Played the Nightdive remastered version
- Yep, it's still Doom. But with more enemy variety, bigger fights, and a meaner shotgun.
- While the level design is better than in Doom 1, most maps still lack any sort of sense of place and there's still occasional "something happened somewhere" nonsense. What the hell was Sandy Petersen smoking when he designed the Spirit World exit area?

title: Deadly Premonition
comment:
- Emulated the Switch version because both the PC and PS3 versions are more or less unplayable
- Bad graphics, bad driving, bad combat, bad audio balancing, bad puzzles, bad level design, bad performance
- Amazing soundtrack
- York is one of the best characters of all time, and the rest of the cast is great as well
- Starts off feeling like a funny bad game but in the end the supposed bad stuff only adds to the personality and makes it way better than it has any right to be
- Nails the Twin Peaks vibes without feeling like a rehash
- The last few hours are completely off the rails in the best way possible

title: Unreal Tournament
comment:
- Good shooting, varied weapons, no brains required
- The single player campaign being just a series of bot matches is fine, but the AI being bad does hold it back especially in team based game modes. The rating is only for single player, multiplayer is obviously better.
- Deathmatch is alright, though looking for guns after respawning can be annoying
- Domination is easily the best mode. More structured than DM and the bots are competent enough to handle it.
- UT's take on Capture the Flag is the worst one I've ever seen and in the running for one of the worst versus modes in general. No time limit, instant respawns, and instant flag returns create a formula for endless stalemates.
- Assault is an interesting gimmick, but clearly too much for the bots to handle
- The map quality ranges from excellent to terrible, and I felt no shame turning god mode on in some of the worst offenders

title: Worshippers of Cthulhu
comment:
- City builders are still not my jam
- The start was alright and easy enough to get into, but once I was supposed to start micro managing people's workplaces and tens of resources it lost me
- Didn't feel like there was a lot of Cthulhu going on outside of the coat of paint

title: We Were Here Forever
comment:
- Like in WWHTogether, the puzzles are quite long and the workload isn't always equally balanced between players
- The Cthulhu puzzle was the highlight, the mechanics made sense and were fun to figure out and work with
- The graveyard was the worst part, the biggest part of the challenge came from the deliberately disjointed hints
- There's a story?

title: Peak
comment: Good, simple co-op game where teamwork matters more than in most. Not much replay value after one successful climb.

title: Eriksholm: The Stolen Dream
comment:
- Very polished for what it is
- The story, while well presented, doesn't seem to go anywhere. At least in the first half it felt like nothing important happened since the opening.
- The gameplay is very linear and limited. Technically it has similarities to Desperados or Shadow Gambit, but each character only has one ability and each room only has one entrance, and at least for the first half of the game you mostly just have one character at a time.
- A better comparison would be A Plague Tale, another very linear story driven game with limited stealth. Ultimately, both just ended up being boring to me.

title: Chants of Sennaar
comment:
- Figuring out the languages was very satisfying, and each one felt unique enough
- The other little puzzle and stealth segments were basic, but added variety
- Worked very well as a pseudo co-op game

title: It Takes Two
comment:
- Really polished in every aspect
- Gameplay stayed fresh by constantly changing up the mechanics. But that also meant that there was very little depth or challenge in any given section.
- The characters never stopped talking or yelling and were overly quippy. Most of the humor didn't land for me.
- The scene with Cutie is genuinely one of the most horrifying scenes in any game (even if the character decisions leading up to it doesn't make a lot of sense)

title: The Beginner's Guide
comment:
- One of them walking sims. Pretty good one.
- I should get back to working on my game

title: We Were Here Expeditions: The FriendShip
comment:
- Only three puzzles, but I think they were on average better than in the other games in the series as they all required lots of active communication, rather than one person waiting for the other to solve their part
- The board game puzzle felt too luck based

title: Escape First Alchemist
comment:
- The puzzles were generally very easy
- Didn't really benefit from co-op
- The narrator was obnoxious

title: F.E.A.R. Perseus Mandate
comment:
- More the same generic shooting, not worth the bad reputation it has. Maybe the drawbacks are more obvious if played immediately after Extraction Point.
- The section right after the ending of the base game was neat
- Weapon variety was completely gone, there was no reason to ever switch away from the shotty and nailgun combo

title: F.E.A.R. Extraction Point
comment: It's more the same, with even less story but with a bit more varied environments.

title: Silent Hill f
comment:
- The story had a bit of a slow start in the first playthrough, but does get interesting around the halfway mark, is good overall
- The ending sets up NG+ in a really interesting way, but it's a trap that doesn't pay off. The gameplay isn't good enough to warrant going through a nearly identical playthrough of a fairly long and linear game. The story didn't go into a more interesting direction either.
- Especially in some of the town sections, the atmosphere was really nice. But it never reached the heights of the PS2 games as all the low resolution graininess was replaced by UE5 stuttering. Also sadly there were a quite a few jump scares that didn't feel very SH to me.
- It didn't feel like there was a proper vision behind the combat design. On one hand it wanted to be an action game with perfect dodges and counters and focus systems, but some of the mechanics were completely absent on Story difficulty, which clearly is the preferred setting. Feels like there should be some middle ground that makes use of all the mechanics but makes the enemies, especially the titty monsters, have less health.
- Could've used way less combat in general to give room for atmosphere building. The monsters stopped being threatening and the gameplay got dull, especially during NG+.
- Inventory management was an unnecessary system. Most of the items were only there to be used as offerings, which didn't feel that meaningful. Maybe it's more important on Hard combat difficulty, but why would anyone want to play that way?
- Some of the puzzle solutions made no sense, which appears to be a localization issue as at least one of them was easier on a higher difficulty. Bit of a mixed bag in terms of puzzles, some very good (hidden shrine) some very bad (scarecrow).
- The school was the highlight with appropriate mix of combat, puzzles, exploration, and backstory.  I especially liked how the main puzzle tied into the school setting.
finished: NG and NG+, (Combat: Story)/(Puzzles: Hard+Lost in the Fog)

title: Metal Gear Solid Delta: Snake Eater
comment:
- The good parts of the original are still mostly there. The camo system is still the best one out there. Lots of variety, whether it comes from different environments, boss fights, or gimmicky sections. Coherent story and reasonable cutscene lengths by Metal Gear standards.
- The End and The Boss are some of the best stealth bosses out there
- Required a mod to get the field of view and camera to a reasonable state
- The very clumsy movement and controls are an endless source of frustration. Just walking around is painful as you get stuck on things due to the automatic cover system, and there's a lack any sort of precision when simply trying to turn around.
- A faster camouflage change menu is a nice improvement, but what this game really needed was a complete overhaul of the camo system so you're not encouraged to switch every three meters.
- The Pain lived up to his name by being utter garbage, not least because of the dreadful swimming mechanics. Might take the "worst boss" title from the killer7 brainy men.
- Maybe this is a skill issue, but there seemed to be no indication of enemy positions at all, be it barks, footsteps, or anything else. The camera was also too janky to be used to look around properly. Either I suck, or figuring out enemy positions involves a lot of trial and error.
- The original had some gameplay flaws (using the PS2's pressure sensitive buttons, excessive menuing when healing...) and Delta isn't an improvement, it just replaces some of the problems with different, worse ones. Beyond the small changes, it's a one-to-one, absolutely pointless remake (if it even is a remake). A downgrade more than anything.
- Just play the Master Collection version of the original. Or the 3DS version. They're probably better.
